reviewText:
I gave up WoW (or World of Warcraft) For this game. Why? You only need one character to play every class. The classes build off of eachother to add diversity to your play style as well as to upgade into more role focused jobs. You can craft your own gear, you can make your own food and you can play 90% of the game ALL BY YOURSELF! You don't have to be in a guild or part of a click. The people who play this game are shockingly friendly and supportive. Dungeons are part of a finder in game. The story line is epic and the cinematics are breathtakeing. The opening video almost had me in tears just because I knew what was happening without any words. Square has really outdone themselves with this title and I can't wait to see how they wow me with FFXV!

Edit: As per a commented question, The sub options come in 30/90/180 day increments and can be set up as recurring (thanks Pasty858). 180 days is roughly $78.

Also, anyone who would like to share in the recruit a friend benefits, message me.

I was a WoW player. I played every expansion, I did HC/Mythic raiding, I spent thousands of hours playing it. If I could go back and get this on launch day instead, I would do it in a heart beat.

If you are an MMO players, this  is hands down the best MMO on the market.  I've played every major MMO since Ultima Online back in the 90s. FFXIV has every element you could want in an MMO and executes them extremely well.

If you like MMOs even a little bit, stop reading and click the buy button.

Really, stop.

Stop it! Go play FFXIV, seriously.

reviewText:
I've never been an MMO player. Briefly played Tera - liked it but found progression slow - and briefly WoW - disliked the combat, just felt like button mashing. I also played Mabinogi for a short while and really disliked the game's mechanics. One day I felt the urge to play one and I knew a friend was planning to start this so I bought it but neither of us started. 9 days ago a friend of mine was looking for people who wanted to start and I decided that if it was in my steam list I may as well try it out. I am now 95.9 hours in according to steam and I love it. I've just hit level 50 and got my Paladin armour and I'm still looking at all the content coming up. As I speak server is going down to patch even more content into the game. So here's the detailed review:

Story

The story is a good one as far as MMOs go (based on my limited experience). I'd equate it to WoW in some ways as FFXIV builds off of an already established lore but is still extremely easy for new players to get into. I don't want to say much about it but Square Enix really put work into making a good story. It teeters a bit at times, especially around the middle (lv30-40 is a bit slow) but it's very enjoyable if you get into it.

Classes

Combat classes are fairly traditional: tank, support, ranged DPS and melee DPS. Still within these wider definitions, each individual class is fairly unique. To add to this you are not restricted to the classes that you pick at the beginning of the game. You will unlock the ability to train any and all classses as you wish which allows for a lot of flexibility. But Oh
recommended: all classes trained beyond the first receive exp gain bonuses which really speeds up the process. This is alongside the quick levelling options which I'll discuss in a later section.\n\nThere's more though! All combat classses have a progression called a "Job" which is earned by reaching a certain point in the story
hoursPlayed: getting a class to lv30 and the corresponding second class to lv15
voteText:
and then finishing the job quest. It's actually really easy to do and it encourages you to try a different role.

All combat classes are unique and don't overlap much at all which is great.

As for crafting classes
helpfulPercent: there's a fair few of them and I have limited experience of them right now but crafting itself isn't just sit there and wait for things to appear. There's an active process and is fairly enjoyable. Just like the combat classes
votesHelpful: new skills are unlocked and it becomes a sort of strategic minigame. Quick synthesis for bulk items is available as well so you don't have to do it for each item.\n\nStill I can see crafting becoming tedious. repetitive and boring at some point but that's no different from any other mmo. Also
votesTotal: unlike the combat classes

the crafting classes aren't really unique.

Combat

The combat system is targetted
commentsCount: which honestly I was sceptical about when first going in as I'm not a big fan of targetted combat but it grows on you. This is mostly to do with how the game feels since you really have to think about movement
column16: positioning
column17: skill orders
column18: skill timing etc. from more or less the beginning of the game. This is a big deal and playing the first 20 or so levels in WoW feels boring and just mashing buttons in a certain order. The 2.5sec global cooldown adds to the strategic element of it too. You have more time to think and decide what move would be appropriate
column19:
but you also have a longer window to be punished for choosing the wrong skill. I honestly think this is way more fun and interesting compared to other games with a much smaller global cooldown.

Another important point is that this game is very controller friendly. It's on the PS3/PS4 with cross platform support so that would be why. I personally play with a controller and it feels very smooth. I don't feel too overwhelmed with skills and I've unlocked all of them for my job with 3 cross skills in use as well (I have 2 full hotbars but it's very easy to switch between them). It's down to preference in the end but the option is really nice to have.

Levelling

There are so many different ways to level it's crazy. Though the main story quest is compulsory
column20:
there are loads of side quests available.

If you think quests are repetitive you can switch over to doing FATES which are events that spawn that give gil (money) and experience to everyone that completes them based on the level of participation.

If that's boring there are many different dungeons to do with solid exp gain on all of them. Duty roullete will give you bonus exp once a day so deffo worth doing that.

No? Then you can do levequests which are contracts to do certain things in certain places which you can get by using one of your levequest allowances (which refill regularly). Levequests are available to crafting classes too and are considered the fastest ways to level them.

Still not enough? Then Guildhests might be for you. These are very similar to levequests but you're put into a duty (instance) with a party and asked to do it as a group. There's a daily bonus on guildhest roullete as well so that's good.

Also
column21: the first time you do a certain dungeon
column22: levequest or guildhest you'll be granted bonus exp which is always a definite plus.\n\nStill too slow? Not enough content? Too repetitive? Well if you're that hard to please then I guess I should tell you that there are these things called logs which grant bonus exp for doing certain things. A hunting log will ask you to kill x number of y
column23:
while a crafting log will give you the list of everything you can craft. The king of all these is the challenge log which refreshes weekly and gives you a lot of exp for completing tasks like "complete 3 dungeons" or "complete 5 levequests".

Honestly there are so many different ways to level that players can pick something that suits them and though some can get repetitive they're fun for the most part.

Endgame

You only need to google the game to see the amount of post lv50 content. The game's been out for about a year and there are things constantly being added. The first expansion is coming out soon so keep an eye out for that. Most people will tell you that lv50 is just the beginning

Conclusion

I honestly think this is the first mmo to seriously impress me with its ability to keep you interested. It doesn't overwhelm you

reviewText:
TL;DR A fantastic, beautiful, well thought out MMO, with amazing polish, a great community and a bright future!

- TL;DR Bullet Points -

PROS:

+ Great and friendly community

+ Good looking and well optimised, with extensive graphical options

+ No need for multiple characters, one character can play ANY of the in game classes, and switch at will

+ Gorgeous world with deep lore

+ In depth crafting system with great reward

+ Huge main story, which feels like a true Final Fantasy story

CONS:

- Loading screens in the world, due to PS3 client limitations (worlds are shared)

- Sometimes overwhelming UI

- Possible overwhelming number of classes on one character, can be difficult to keep track and keep focus

- Monthly fee, which may put some people off

- Big time investment required to get to enjoy everything in the game (as with any MMO)



- The long written part! -

Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is the completely reworked and almost entirely remade version of Square Enix's latest MMO. Initially it came out, just as Final Fantasy XIV, on the 22nd of September 2010. Unfortunately, it was absolutely terrible, and is still regarded as one of the worst MMO's in recent years, if not ever. The UI was particularly bad, but the problems were pretty much onmipresent. Graphcis were gorgeous but ridiculously unoptimised, bad gameplay mechanics, etc. However! This is NOT that game! I can't stress this enough!

In December 2010, Naoki Yoshida was brought in as the new Director and producer, to try and make the game better. While some of these changes did start to make the game more playable, Square Enix, feeling (rightly so, some would say) very ashamed about this initial release (which I will call 1.0 from now on), and also worried about the damage it would do to the Final Fantasy brand, deciced to close down this game and completely rebuild it from the ground up. The servers for 1.0 closed on November the 11th 2012.

The rerelease, called A Realm Reborn (the current game!), launched on August 27th 2013, with a PS3 version coming out on the same day. With the transition to the new game, Square implemented lots of cool in game lore explanations for the upcoming dramatic changes, and it is now a part of the game's story (which I think is really cool).

ARR is a fantastic MMO in nearly every aspect. It does, of course, have it's problems, but I have yet to find an MMO which doesn't (not even WoW). I have been playing MMO's since Everquest, and would say ARR is now my favourite of them all, from WoW to EQ to SWTOR to EVE, etc. I feel they have gotten the formula just right.

For the purchase on Steam you get the game itself, along with a month of playtime, so I would definitely recommend this if you think it might be for you (there is also a trial on the Square Enix website, but this would mean you don't have to reinstall if youstick with it!).

In terms of gameplay, it follows what I think would be fairly described as a rough following of the Western style MMO formula, with some key differences:

- Classes are not one-per-character". On your character you can switch between and unlock every single combat

reviewText:
Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is an MMORPG. The rebooted/revamped version of the atrocious Final Fantasy XIV, and the 100th billionth game in the Final Fantasy franchise.

FFXIV:ARR is much like what WoW used to be when WoW was good. They took much of what made WoW great back in vanilla/The Burning Crusade and used it to shape FFXIV:ARR, adding a modern touch on top.

After the failure of Final Fantasy XIV, Square Enix got rid of most of the development team and learnt from their mistakes. What they've ended up with is an amazing MMO with tons of content and fine details to keep you playing for months.

The game offers a unique class system much like FFXI, where you're free to change your class at any time you wish, by simply changing your weapon to that of the class you wish to equip. There's 9 classes to choose from, with each playing a different role: tanks, healers, and DPS's. Each of these classes later turn into jobs, offering more abilities for you to gain and unlock. There's also 8 crafting classes, and 3 gathering classes available.

The game is filled with various dungeons, raids, and trials which are essentially boss fights.

Many MMOs lack true end game content, however FFXIV:ARR is mostly focused on end game content. Many consider the game to not start until you reach level 50 (which takes anywhere from a few days to a few weeks, depending on how you play and how often you play). The game offers many dungeons for leveling, and even more for late game. Many of which are harder versions of leveling dungeons. On top of this, there's multiple raids ranging from your traditional raids with many players (24 in this case), or smaller 8 player raids. Finally, for those who love boss fights there's plenty of trials to keep you entertained. These are mostly primal fights with varying levels of difficulty.

There's tons of gear in the game each offering unique looks, allowing for huge amounts of customisation. In terms of character customisation, there’s quite a few options for you to choose from. There’s 5 different races, with each offering two sub-races of sorts. For example, your traditional “human” race has both midlanders and highlanders. The game does not offer sliders for things such as eye shape, nose shape, etc., but instead has four different types for you to select, with each sub-race having a different selection. As well as this, there’s plenty of hairstyles for you to choose from, with a wide range of colours to select as well as a highlight colour.

The game’s OST is absolutely amazing, and possibly one of the best I’ve ever heard in a game. There’s tons of tracks with unique songs for each field location, dungeon, trial, raid, and everything else.  I highly recommend checking it out, even if you do not purchase the game.
The game is updated every couple of months adding more items, dungeons, primal fights, new music, and much more. So there’s always plenty to do.

FFXIV:ARR is subscription based. You can pay $12/month for 1 character per world, with a maximum of 8 characters. Or you can pay $15/month for 8 characters per world, with a maximum of 42 characters. Though with the way classes work, you won’t be needing more than a single character usually, so the limit is hardly an issue. Some people are turned off by subscription fees, however $12/month is a small price to pay for such a great game, which constantly gets more content. The lack of F2P or B2P also prevents P2W aspects, and usually means the community is better in general.

Overall, Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn has to be the best MMORPG I’ve ever played. The sheer amount of content has kept me hooked for over 400 hours, and will continue to do so as the months go on. If you’re looking for a great MMORPG to play, and have the money to invest, I could not recommend this more.

(Alright, time to give this review an overhaul now that I've officially given this game 1000 hours of my life. Just gonna add in some extra tidbits here and there.)

FFXIV has easily become my favorite MMO. Easily. And it's weird, because I just sort of downloaded it like, (shrug) yeah, I'll check it out, why not. But then after a while, I realized, 'Holy ♥♥♥♥, I'm having SO much fun.' The thing is, I've never viewed Final Fantasy as an MMO sort of game. It was always the main console games for me (FFVII, FFVIII, FFIX, etc.). So FFXIV, and FFXI for that matter, was never something I even looked at or took interest in. But hey, now I'm a full-fledged passenger aboard the FF MMO hype train.

I really don't even know where to start with this review. A part of me just wants to go EVERYTHING IS AWESOME THIS IS AWESOME AND THAT IS AWESOME AND IT'S ALL SPECTACTULAR. A+ review. I don't really think I'll be able to cover everything I want to, but I'm gonna take a shot at (some of) it:

Stay awhile and listen (!!)
Whenever I think MMO, I think, half-♥♥♥♥♥ basic story. And that's fine, because it's all about the gameplay and getting the gear and doing the dungeons and getting your rake so you can go farming. And whenever I think Final Fantasy, I think, five-star story that will leave you with great memories for years and years to come.

FFXIV actually has a good story to it. And I got pumped for it when I saw that opening cutscene, a scene that I still watch over and over from time to time. Now, the story isn't out of this world, but I did enjoy it a lot. Everything built up to make the end boss much more satisfying. And there were cutscenes. Tons of cutscenes. So many. Which can be good or bad depending on the person obviously. I appreciated it, and it did immerse me into the story more.

Edit: And now that I have gotten much farther in the story and, again, have spent 1000 hours of my life with it, I can say now that I absolutely love the story in this game. I mean, the story was good in 2.X (and got real ♥♥♥♥ing crazy around 2.55), but with Heavensward (3.0), I just sort of realized how much I love these characters, I love the story that's going on, and I care. I HAVE CRIED REAL TEARS MULTIPLE TIMES. I have gotten angry, I have been shocked, I have felt many emotions through the course of this game. Other games I'm like cool, cool, cool, let's get on to the fighting. Here, I will shush the ♥♥♥♥ out of anyone who won't let me finish my cutscene. Like a good mini-movie ayyyyy.

Eye Candy (!!)
In the manner of my kobold friends, this game is gorgeous, stunning, beautiful! I mean really, I'm not even sure how to phrase how much I appreciate the graphics in this game. I think I was killing this buffalo type creature the other day, and the sun was rising (Yes, there is a weather/day/night cycle system. Yeah, it's awesome.), and you know when the sun is shining in someone's eyes and you can see just how pretty their eye color is? Yeah, well I thought this buffalo looked sweet as ♥♥♥♥ in the sunlight. So that, but transfer it to every single zone and x100 because I can view the zones during night/day/dusk/dawn/etc. Also, the newest zones for the 3.0 expac are gorgeous, except now I can just stare at all the beauty while flying and listening to the banging music and ijustlovethisgame. And I still don't think I expressed how much everything pierces my soul. I can't guys, just. Max settings 4 lyf suck ittttt~~~~


C-c-c-combo breaker (!!)
Combat to me is great. I have never played a tab-target mmo before, so the entire system was new to me. I came from a somewhat action-combat oriented MMO, but I find myself really enjoying the combat here. However, in the beginning levels, it is a little lackluster. You don't have as many abilities open to you though, so obviously you're gonna be restricted to your basic 1-2 combo over and over (sometimes even less depending on the class).

Aside from just talking about combat in itself, there are an array of dungeons and trials to do. 4-man, 8-man, 24-man parties all there. There are roughly around 90 (I'm including all the different difficultly levels plus counting floors/turns as their own) dungeons/trials/raids so far. Some trials have a normal, hard, and extreme version, and some dungeons have a hard version as well (although the hard versions are completely different from the normal version, so it's a whole new dungeon in itself. Nice move SE /proudofyouthx). The mechanics for a lot of these are super fun to me, although a bit daunting when you first start out. Some say it's like memorizing a dance with how crazy some fights get. I dig them, though. A lot. I find myself replaying a lot of the dungeons/trials just because the fight is amazing, not to farm gear or whatnot (finalfightof3.0imlookingatyou)

The dungeon/trail/raid private instances aren't just it though. There's still plenty going on in the open world, like FATEs and Hunts. Tons of people party up for those, granted you are in a pretty populated server.

We are Sex Bob-omb (!!)
Okay. If you haven't heard already, the music in the game is pretty stellar. Go on any FFXIV boss fight youtube video and people will be raving about how sweet the music is. And it's true. The music, especially for the boss fights, gets you SO pumped (finalfightof3.0lookingatyouagain). It's the kind of music where you hear it as the battle starts and you're just like 'Awww man. ♥♥♥♥'s gonna be intense'.

But it's not just the boss fights (although those are what get the most attention). Just about anywhere you go has some nice music playing. And I actually notice it (!!). I say this because there's some music that blends in with the atmosphere, like in most movies/games/commercials/etc., which is great (and perfect for most scenarios), but then there's the music that jumps out at you. That just compells you to look it up on the internet later. And that's the kind of music that I dig. And FFXIV has plenty of that. The soundtrack for the Heavensward expansion couldn't come out any faster. I crave it.

It's just not my style (!!)
So aside from the aforementioned lackluster combat in the beginning of the game, I figured I should put the couple of things that aren't so nice about FFXIV.

When you first play FFXIV, you may notice the lack of people talking in the chat. It makes the game feel dead, but it's really not (so far from it). Due to gold spammers (or so I hear), everyone just moved over to linkshells, which is basically custom channels. So join a linkshell and FC (guild), and your chat will be lively as normal. But that can be a turn-off to newcomers. Heavily populated cities (depending on your server) may have people talking in the shout/yell/say chat as normal though. Also, the newest 'lobby' area that came with the 3.0 expac is very lively in shout chat. Mostly because the gold spammers haven't reached us there yet hah hhahHAHAH HA.

That brings me to gold spammers. Depending on the server you choose, you may not get that many gold spammers, or you may get a hell of a lot. And they do PM you or spam the chat from time to time. But, again, this can be a turn-off for some players, especially since this is a subscription based MMO.

Cutscenes that occur during party events, but I won't get into that here (!!)
(Chorus)(Outro)(Fade-out)
I still left out a lot of the tidbits that I just absolutely love about the game, but alas, this totally short review will have to suffice. I surprisingly ended up loving this game, and you should check it out if it sounds like something you're even remotely interested in. I love it lots. Square Enix and Final Fantasy have (again) taken my soul hostage and I'm ok with that.

reviewText:
Overview:

Incredibly polished and well endowed MMO. Almost every setting is tweakable and supports controllers as well, you get a game that offers you everything you payed for and witholds none of it.

It also uphold the name of Final Fantasy in good faith, probably a lot better than the newer FF games. The combat is a bit repetitive however, you've got a wealth of content to discover and quests that reward you well; dungeons from level 15 and up and lots of end-game content (but be prepared for hardcore type groups for the real end-game content, statics with schedules).

Pretty soon there's going to be an expansion and new classes so there's much more to look forward to as the game ages. The developer has done a great job at supporting the game thus far and I've seen no signs of them slowing down.

+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
Here's my breakdown between the positives and negatives of FFXIV:RR.
+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+

-------(Positive things)-------

+ Good writing!

+ Lots of content!

+ The Hildibrand questline is the best questline in any MMO hands down.

+ You've got lots of customization for your character / your HUD / and homes if you're rich enough.

+ Generally a nice community for an MMO except for the occasional try-hard who gets unreasonably upset.



------(Negative things)-------

- This game is fetch quest hell, if you despise fetch quests more than anything then I do not recommend you play this game.

- The journey from level 1 to level 50 isnt that exciting. (this pretty much goes for all MMOs)

- RNG will occupy the vast majority of your end game time spent. Repeatedly run the same content over and over and over until you get that pretty blouse you wanted to glamour.

- If you want to stick to 1 class for running content, the gameplay will get stale fairly fast, which isnt unique to FF, many MMO titles suffer from this. There's no traits or choice options to customize your fighting or spells, just flat stat increases that don't change the gameplay in any way other than just becoming stronger. (And your strength primarily comes from your gears item-level) You will be at level 50 with typically around 3 abilitys you need to use repeatedly for combat, and then 3 special situation skills to use in.. special situations and 2 super abilities you save for oh-♥♥♥♥ moments.

This varies between the classes but I played as a White Mage, so basically my job was to repeatedly hit the 2 button to cast cure, and then sometimes use a spell called Esuna to remove conditions from myself or others, and then cast an AOE that made HP regen (which you need to keep refreshing for the party once it wears off). This was not very fun to me, so you have to rely on the game to throw variety in the dungeons or enemies to spice things up.

Usually it just boils down to memorizing boss mechanics and hoping nobody screws up. So essentially you're a bot following a strictly scripted fight and if you deviate from that you're most likely going to fail; This might be different for other people, but this is just how I felt after a while of doing end-game content.

-------

But, feel free to give it a go yourself! There's a free 14 day trial for FFXIV, so don't let my opinions get in the way of a potentially good time when you could test drive it for yourself. As far as MMOs come and whats avaliable at the moment, I still recommend you give FF a try since it's one of the best subscription based MMOs out there right now. But this one just isnt for me.

(I Still recommend it for MMO lovers!)

At first time maybe the combat looks slow, easy and very simple but you are not going to feel the true difficulty of this game until you face a Primal in Hard Mode. Get your butt ready for die a lot and more if you do it with random people.

reviewText:
After Final fantasy XIV 1.0 was a gigantic flop, Square Enix was brave enough to give the title a reboot.

With success!

A Realm Reborn is really fun. This already starts with the story which is very long in my opinion. The atmosphere and the music are wonderful. Every detail in the game is lovely designed. There are so many possibilities in the game to kill time. For example, there are FATEs which are events where you must fight in groups against world bosses and other opponents. Even if you've reached max level, you can still enter old dungeons because your level gets capped and you can enjoy them with newer players. If you're bored with your current class, then you don't have to create a new character. Just change your weapon, and you can play as another class. I really like that idea since I don't like to have multiple characters.

If you're a Final Fantasy or MMORPG fan, then you should definitely give this title a try. It's one of the greatest MMORPG's in recent years. I've never had so much fun with an MMO like with this one.

reviewText:
See, I don't normally play MMO's. If I try one, it usually captures my attention for a solid week, then I lose interest, uninstall it, and never play it again.

This game? Oh man oh man. This game is great. I've only ever played free MMO trash around the web, but this one is by far THE BEST MMO I have ever played.

The combat is like you should expect; if you've played any other MMO, it plays similarly to what you would expect out of an MMO. There are a variety of classes that you can choose from as your battlecraft classes and, the best part, you can have every class on one character. This is especially helpful when you're doing end-game raid stuffs. Form one team, and depending on what your team has leveled, you can form different groups with the same team.

When I first started playing this game, as a low level I thought the gameplay was spectacular. Everything felt so fresh, and I felt like there was a bunch of things about the game I had yet to discover. Boy, was I right. Once I hit 50 (the max level for every class BEFORE Heavensward, which will increase that cap to 60), I felt like the game suddenly opened up to me. To this day, I still find that I have a LOT to do.

If you're looking for a great MMO to play and don't mind a monthly fee, look no further. Final Fantasy XIV will surely fill your MMO needs.

reviewText:
Since I've been at it for a while, and I'm waiting for servers to come back up, I think it's time for a bit of a review.

Pros:
-Beautiful if your system can run it, but the ability to downgrade graphics settings enough to run on a fairly low end machine makes the game possible for more people.
-Great controller support if that happens to be your thing.
-Everything feels fluid. Classes are given very large kits and balance spamable abilites with complex rotations and cooldowns. Things are smiple enough to let casual players compete most content but exceptional players exceed and tackle the highest level raiding conent when it's released.
-Large amounts of midcore content while still providing hardcore and casual content.
-The learning curve while long is actually fairly short compared to most mainstream MMO I've played, and you are able to gain an understanding of things faster due to the ability to level/hotswap out different classes as you please.
-Reasonbly diverse class list genrally offers a lot of different and unique playstyles.
-The dev team is small, but very dedicated and seem to listen to fan feedback reasonably well and puts out major content updates every few months with smaller minor patches to hold everybody over.
-A lot of stuff to do, and plenty of replayability.
-Final Fantasy tier sound track is naturally beautiful.
-You can have all classes on one character. Hotswapable, including crafting and gathering classes.
-Fishing
-Catgirls
-The game is absolutely full of references to different things and amusing humor. Sometimes it's subtle, sometimes it's not. Either way they know what they are doing tears at your soul and they aren't sorry. I like to think of the Square Enix FFXIV dev team as Dr. Evil from the Austin Powers movies.
-It comes with an actually good story, this is extremely rare these days in MMOs but it will destroy your heart.
-Full cutscene/story replay feature for all those people who skip everything and want to figure out the story later.
-It also comes with absurd amounts of side content that only exist to amuse you.
-Everything is put together so nicely. One of it's best features overall is that it doesn't do anything badly.
-Catgirls
-Lots of in game events, probably about once a month or so there is some kind of seasonal event. During some seasonal events including Halloween, Christmas, Easter, Valentines Day, and many more they actually update massive portions of the game thematically. These may also give everything for aestetic gear to mounts.
-Magnificently done atmosphere and fight design.
-Lots of unique content in terms of fight/boss design. Some fights may have overlapping mechanics that were used in other fights but nearly all of the content feels completely different.
-It is still very early in the game's life cycle. If it's anything like it's mother MMO, Final Fantasy XI, then we are close to a quarter done with thousands of hours of content already in the game.
-Y'shtola



Cons:
-The game is an MMO and can be grind heavy.
-Some gear is gated behind time gates (ie only a few pieces of gear a week) and while this cap always gets removed after a while, it adds an unneeded wait for gear.
-The difficulty spike can get a bit high at times when you are new to the game and running content for the first time without watching a proper guide.
-Old content is reused a lot and that's ok to many because much of it is heavily replayable, but the way gear syncing (Limiting stats on gear that has outpaced older content) is done makes some old content far too easy due to stats not being synced low enough and making non-current content faceroll easy.
-While the devs are actively trying to fix things, sometimes the ends don't justify the means with gear. The best example of this would be the relic weapon questline where you grind for gear comparable or better to the best raiding gear at the time, but the steps are meant to be a masochistic grind so it kinda fills it's own purpose.
-On the North American servers excluding Gilgamesh and Balmung (Which are both often locked from character creation due to high population) have rampant amounts of RMT offers sent through private chat and not enough is done to combat it.
-Crafting can often feel trivial in terms of actual combat gear, but as of 3.2, this issue seems to have been eliminated for the most part.
-Much of the seasonal event gear is free if you attended the event, but is put in the cash shop after a long period of time downing the exclusivity of having experienced the event. This is more of a personal gripe.
-There is a cash shop purely for visual items (Almost only special sets that were free at one time and a few other special items)
-Dps que can occationally become unreasonable
-The selling system/overflow storage system works off retainers, basically servants that you can customize. You are given two by default which is enough for many players, but they offer more (Up to six) for a small monthly fee. Very upsetting considering the game is purchased plus pay to play although extra retainers aren't that neccessary for most.
-You will re-run old content a lot. While this keeps que times shorter for people trying to level alternate classes, it can be old after a while, but you are given many options for how you level.

reviewText:
I will recommend this game to anyone. My hours are increasing by the days that I play.
This game will steal your life and never make you want to go outside. Lol. Just kidding.

Pros:

NO GENDERBIND. I love this, I can be all the classes without having to make a new character, I don't have to be a certain race to play all the classes. I do everything on one character and it's amazing like that.

Crafting is awesome, Most crafting mmos are pretty straight foward. You get the materials, Boom done. That's not it works in FFXIV, In this game, You use your skills, get the materials and use your skills to make the material you're going for. It's like a little mini game to keep you interested. It's a very fun thing to do in game.

Community: Omg, where do I start? All the mmos I have played. I immediately go solo, and do everything on my own unless I'm forced to party. This community is WONDERFUL. They're nice, and not rude at all. I've only experienced one rude person in my hours. The guilds are wonderful and want to help new players level up. I was afraid to join a guild but when I did. It was lovely. I was welcomed and offered help when I got stuck. Dungeons, you can't do them alone so having an amazing community is a good thing.

Story: The story is literally the only reason why I got this game in the first place, but knowing what I know now. It's a great game all together. The story is engaging, interesting and definately is worth the sub. and with Heavensward. There's even more story now. So it's really worth it to enage fully in the story.

End game: Past level 50, or past level 60. This is where this game jumps to the top of my list as Best MMos.
Simply because. There's simply NEVER nothing to do. There's so many things to do, to keep you busy. Right when you hit 50. The game opens up even more, You can travel to new places. Fight harder dungeons and earn tombstones for amazing glamours.


Music/Scenery The soundtrack is amazing. I find myself listening to it most days when I'm on and taking in the beautiful graphics. When it rains. You can see your avatar wet, when it's windy. Your hair blows. It's very cool to me at least.

Races: Also, The races are awesome. You pick one race, then there's two more. Like Miqote. You can be a seeker or the sun or a keeper of the moon. Lots of things to pick from in characther creation. Amazing selections. Lots of hairstyles. Wide Variety of eyes, highlights for hairs and voices etc. It's very nice to have so much selection. ^_^

Cons: I only have a one con.

Grinding can get repeative, you will have to multiple dungeons, and fight along the same monsters etc etc. That can get boring. But some dungeons are tricky so it's better if you know what you're doing.


This game is great. It's worth the sub and worth the extra money to get heavensward. I will continue to play it and tell people to jump into the wonderful world of Eorzea. :D

reviewText:
Honestly, I never review games. All I do is READ them, but this game really caught my eye and I truly believe it deserves one.
Final Fantasy XIV has to be one of the most fun MMORPG's on the market to date. You jump right into the story and feel like you're listening to someone read a really well written book. It draws you in and makes you want to hear more and more with every passing hour.
First off I would like to point out that Final Fantasy XIV has one of the most beautiful soundtracks I have ever heard in my entire gaming life. It fits really well with every location you reach, and the battle music is one that will bring back memories for all the Final Fantasy Vets who play .
Second, I would like to say that the graphics quality is out of this would for any MMO to date that I know of. it may only be DX9 but they gave thee game a full graphics overhaul. Playing on the lowest settings gives you STANDARD DEF CONSOLE graphics, but when you crank up the settings, BAM! you look close and every bit of clothing has texture, every shadow is perfectly cast, and the over all exicution is remarkable.
Finally I would like to say that after over 200 hours of in game time, I have made many friends. The community is wonderful. I remember when I was about a level 14 White Mage, I was taking on a level 17 monster and I was low on health. Another Healer out of the blue healed me and a Black Mage helped me defete the enemy and gave me about 5000gil to buy better gear. Everyone playing this game seems to help one another as best they can whenever needed and that is probably the best part of it all.

Personal Rating for this game would be a 9/10 just because sometimes when you stop playing for about a week or two and come back to it, you may get confused on where to go and it leaves you to figure it all out. but other than that little disadvantage, I have to say that this is an all around perfect game. And the edition of multi class gaming on one character makes it stand out from all MMOS I have played.

Now that that's out of the way, enjoy your opening scene filled with you stuck in the back of a cart/ship on your way to one of Eorzea's city states, which you pick based on your starting class. Along the way, you are introduced to a bunch of nobodies who become sombodies and then nobodies again when all is said and done. Luckily this was rectified somewhat in the HW expansion as beginning with the first quest all NPCs save for a few have new VAs' that are actually british instead of the Sam Riegel and Liam O Brian being hammered into your ear for 3/4ths of the story.

Market Board prices can be high, depends on the item

I've been playing this game since its closed beta phase 2, which is about one and a half year ago now. I can recommend this to anyone who's ready to pay the monthly subscription fee.
In terms of entertainment<->money spent ratio, this game wins over many, many others in my library.

To get more into detail:
- very casual design, although it offers challenging endgame content as well
- many alternatives in terms of what to do, you're not bound to farm dungeons if you'd rather craft or gather items or do something else entirely
- wonderful music underlining the game and its scenes
- nice graphics, even on weaker machines
- crossplatform play (PS3/PS4/PC)
- frequent new content
- many story-driven dialogs and cutscenes, entertaining for those who are interested
- easy-to-understand classes and gameplay but challenging to master
- pay-to-play but therefore not pay-to-win
- incredibly nice gamepad controls, beats keyboard and mouse even, trust me
- devoted developers, yes they actually listen to the community
- regular Q&A livestreams + new content showcasing called Letters from the Producer Live"

reviewText: A spectacular redemption of the original Final Fantasy XIV, A Realm Reborn turned one of the worst MMOs of all time into one of the very best. FFXIV: ARR combines elements from RIFT, WoW, Guild Wars 2, and a whole host of MMOs to create a fabulous gestalt of MMO mechanics, one that offers more and more the further you go. While TOR is still my favorite MMO due to it's excellent storytelling, FFXIV is definitely my favorite MMO in terms of it's mechanics, though the story here is pretty good too. Set a few years after a fiery apocalypse destroyed the land of Eorzea, the world is just about getting back up on it's feet after the cataclysm. However, the warlike and expansive Garlean Empire has other plans, seeking to subdue the violent and destructive Primals that make their home in Eorzea: by any means necessary. While suffering from a lack of voice acting and an exceptionally slow start, the mysteries and questions of the FFXIV story are compelling enough that you want to see how it all turns out. Overall, while it doesn't have too many ideas of it's own, FFXIV's polish and quality are more than enough to compensate. Looking for the pinnacle of the hotkey based MMO? Look no further.

reviewText:
Top notch MMO
Freedom to choose Europa, Americas, or Japan servers
Graphically brilliant, uses around 80-90% of my 780ti at 2560x1980 (21:9), maximum settings and uses it well.
Mouse/Keyboard or Console gamepad both available for use, each with their own specialized interface (Very customizable too).

Great character creation, 5+1 Races, with two cultural diversities each.
8+1 combat classes, 9+4 advanced specializations called jobs. ALL are available to each character.
8 crafting classes, 3 gathering. Again ALL available to each character.
Heck, be a full time fisherman if you want.

Writing which is rich in story, world establishment and humour of all ranges.
Gameplay and story start off easy and at a smooth pace, but eventually amounts to huge depth and progression.
Seasonal moods are refreshing and explored in full, all year round.

No pitiful pay-to-win or limit breaking cash shops. Simply a costume/dye, mount and mini pet store for the most narcissistic among us.

AMAZING COMMUNITY (I play with Japanese players, so I can't speak for the rest)

The only thing that might let the game down is that voice acting is reserved for critical moments only, but more is being added quite regularly.

I recommend all interested in RPGs, Social functions, and MMOs in general to give it a try, even people new to Final Fantasy will feel welcome.
Be warned- You may just get sucked in for the long trip, I certainly enjoyed the ride.

reviewText:
So, I've been around the MMO block more than a few times. World of Warcraft, Star Wars The Old Republic, The Secret World, Age of Conan, both D&D online games, Champions Online, D.C. Universe Online, Rift, and so on... but this one is definitely one of the better ones I've played.

Lemme put it this way. I've been a WoW player for the better part of eight years now. I recently picked up this game about midway through the WoW 6.1 content and started playing it right before Heavensward came out, then kept on going with my Miqo'te.

So how much have I gotten into this game this time around? When WoW came out with 6.2 -I didn't care-. New raid, new zone, new loot, new mounts, etc. I don't give a crap, I'm too busy going through Dravinia.

Pros:
- A very strong and engaging story with good characters.
- The ability to make one character, but swap between character classes post-creation. This is also used to get the upgraded versions of classes (i.e. Lv30 Thaumaturge + Lv15 Archer = Black Mage).
- An in depth crafting system that is very addictive to work with.
- The ability to have a chocobo partner who acts as both mount and fighting companion.
- 22 Individual character classes/jobs based on the classic Final Fantasy job system.
- 11 crafting and gathering classes for making equipment, potions, etc.
- Five unique playable races with highly customizeable appearances and two main variants for each race. Six if you get the Heavensward expansion.

Cons:
- Game will require you to grind via dungeons/levequests around the 40-50 stretch to continue the story (you will constantly run into the 'your level is not high enough to continue' issue).
- You can't sell things in the Market/Auction House until around level 20, so making money early on is difficult.
- You can only send mail to people on your friend's list, so you can't send mail between alts.

reviewText:
Do you like Final Fantasy 14?
Their early work was a little too unfinished for my tastes, but when Final Fantasy XIV A Realm Reborn came out in 2013, I think they really came into their own, commercially and artistically. The whole game has a clear, crisp gameplay, and a new sheen of consummate professionalism that really gives the game a big boost. It's been compared to Guild Wars 2, but I think FF14 has a far more bitter, cynical sense of humor.
In 2015, SquareEnix released this, Heavensward, their most recent expansion. I think their undisputed masterpiece is the fight against Ultima Weapon, a boss fight so enjoyable, most people probably don't dodge all of his abilities. But they should, because it's not just about the pleasures of conformity, and the importance of trends, it's also a personal statement about the developers themself.

If you like MMOs play this, if you don't like MMOs then you haven't played this one long enough. ffxiv is getting bigger and better than any other mmo and if you want to invest in a game with a fruitful future ahead of it, then this is the one.

Combat is sharp, fluid, and the combos work well; especially when you're decently leveled and don't have peasant abilities. The class/crafting system is also outstanding, and adds tenfolds of gameplay that's worth investing in (if you're worried about leveling said crafting/fighting class, then you'll be relieved to hear that exp bonus' are awarded the greater the level between your current class vs your highest).

Some interesting aspects about the world and storyline to consider:
-The entire planet begins to recognise your character as you gain levels and further yourself, random NPCs will know who you are and its generally pretty cool to come across games that do that.

-Story is of  high standard, there isn't much voice acting in the beginning, but once you start accessing the non-3-year-old content you'll realise SE has been putting even more effort into their story quests.

-Not just the main story either, each class and job comes with their own unique storyline which also progresses your abilities, these get real intense, probably better than the main story in the short run.

reviewText:
I liked FF14: ARR up until the expansion.

I've played a lot of MMOS (I think at least 30 now) and there are certain things I look for, and really enjoy an MMO having. It doesn't have to, but it gets a big plus in my book if it does. One having interesting and complicated enough mechanics that when you actually finish a boss for the first time, or a dungeon run, it feels like an achievement; that you had to work for it, but it was worth it. The second is having the ability to have different playstyles; the ability to tune your characters closer to how you want to play. The third is an engaging, interesting, and above all USEFUL crafting system.

FF14 had 2 of the three; there's no skill trees at all, and not really any way to modify your gear; there's BiS and that's about it. You can do vanity gear over it though, so at least you can look different then every other player the same level as you. Still, the mechanics were awesome, I loved the music and a lot of the themes of the dungeon, and actually LOOKED FORWARD to gathering and crafting, because people LIKED getting HQ gear and useful items later.

The world was engaging to look around. The story was... well... decent for an FF game (I don't care for FF games in general myself, I played this because I liked it as an MMO). There was always plenty to do, plenty to collect, plenty to save for, etc.

That changed with the expansion. First off, the new maps are a horrid PAIN to get around. They made them HUGE with the intent that It'll look cool when you fly around" and obviously did not give a damn about people who had to hoof it

reviewText:
I have been playing MMOs since starting on Everquest and moving on to Guild Wars and World of Warcraft and unfortunately for several years there haven't been any games which have really been able to grab my attention in the way the earlier MMOs did.  Modern MMOs seem to have devolved into a quick single player race to maximum level where there is no incentive to even read a quest log, before jumping onto the gear grinding treadmill and ultimately running out of things to do shortly afterwards.

FINAL FANTASY XIV: A Realm Reborn has finally changed that, this is the first MMO I have played in recent years which has an interesting, well written story line and actually forces you to complete multi player content in order to progress from time to time.  The crafting system in this game is also incredibly well thought out and rewarding, it is not simply a case of gathering a few materials and pressing a button instead you have to think carefully about strategies to craft each item.  The other thing that also grabbed me about this game was just how beautiful the world is, from the scenery to the chaaracters the game looks stunning and the soundtrack is also top notch.

The game isn't without its faults, one of the main issues at low level is the combat system has a very long GCD and until your character gets some extra skills which are off the GCD this can make combat seem very slow at first.  I think the developers should have introduced a few more 'off GCD' skills earler in the levelling process for some of the classes as this was my main gripe at low level.  That said it doesn't take too long before things start to improve and later on in the game once you have all your skills you can often find yourself wishing the GCD was a bit longer!

One last point worth mentioning is that the community seems to be great, obviously I can't generalise for everyone playing the game but I have found most people are very friendly and helpful.  This goes as much for people outside of your Free Company (guild) as those in it.  I have bumped into more random strangers who have offered to lend a helping hand and explain things in this game than any other I can remember.

To sum it up this is a great game that you can really immerse yourself in.  It has plenty of depth and everthing before maximum level seems tangible and enjoyable rather than something to grind through.  This means you can enjoy the journey rather than worrying about the destination.

reviewText:
I won't lie, I was skeptic. Heavily skeptic. Like, I thought this was worse than Dead Island skeptic.

Square-Enix's track record has been far from amazing in terms of Final Fantasy titles as of late. Final Fantasy XIII almost cemented my lack of trust in them, and watching the disaster that was XIV 1.0, I just stopped keeping track altogether. They'd lost their magic much harder than I could imagine.

This game is lucky I knew someone else who was into A Realm Reborn. At first, I had to laugh at the fact he was still paying for a lousy, broken, boring MMO, but then I started watching. I hadn't realised XIV had ended it's world and restarted again, and I was confused when I found the game to be a lot more interesting than I remember. It shut me the hell up.

I decided to dive into this head first, give it a shot, see if it would be something I could get into. After all, I knew people playing it already, it would be a party based activity, something I haven't done in a while.
But as you can tell by the amount of hours currently sunk into it, I didn't really need to know anyone prior.

This game sunk it's teeth in. Hard.

I'm not someone that comes from a massive MMO background. The last one I had played and gotten into was almost 10 years ago. It would be difficult to know if I could recommend this game over other MMOs, or even other games. Although you would probably do this anyway, I recommend looking at gameplay footage and deciding for yourself. I can personally say I've had more fun with this than I was expecting, and keep coming back.

Community is pretty good (on Cerberus anyway, and from what I've found from watching other players). Yes, there are a few bad eggs, but considering the MMO and other online games I've come from, this isn't a problem. Every community will have the ragequitters, the griefers and the thieves, but they are so scarce. PvP is probably the main place you'll find these people, if at all.

There are a handful of nitpicks, most of them are rather minor, such as the voice acting at points sucking the emotion out of a moment, usually in a single word (this seems to be a SE staple(seriously stop hiring the worst actors to play big roles)) and the HUD does not scale with windowed mode, so it's very easy, if you're running a smaller window, for your screen to get cramped with icons, even if you do shrink them down. But they are nitpicks, nothing that stops the game for me at all.

All I can say is, there is a large chunk of time that I have sunk into it and I do not regret it*.

*okay I regret it a little. I could've been saving the world or learning to speedrun a game or something else with the time I've spent on this.

reviewText:
Tried this game at a friend's behest.  First impressions were nice.  The game is true to its Final Fantasy heritage, and provides the atmosphere you would expect from any FF title.  Graphics were great by MMO standards, but not really up to what you would expect from a current single player Square Enix game.  It sets up a nice story, tho the cutscenes all use in-game models and feel poorly acted/animated.  Overall the mood the game creates is a good one, and one I would enjoy playing in.

That is, if the gameplay itself were at all enjoyable.

As soon as I got into the combat, I immediately groaned.  It's WoW.  The game sticks to the most basic overdone combat system possible.  Target a thing.  Press your skill keys in rotation to damage it.  It starts autoattacking you.  You take damage from that.  You step outside the AoE markers to avoid taking any extra.  Eventually, one of you dies.  Repeat ad infinitum.  Dungeons follow the same formula too.  Tank soaks aggro because autoattacks are unavoidable, healer mitigates that incoming damage, everyone else kills the stuff that's focusing the tank.  Pull a wave, do that.  Pull another, do that.  Reach the boss, do that with a few extra distractions you need to run and deal with in between hitting it.

I wanted to love this game, but sticking in the most samey, widely cloned MMO combat system just leaves it lumped right in the same group as 90% of other MMOs out there.  Why?  They're capable of being innovative.  They could have just as easily made it into a XII-style open-world exploration into menu-based RPG encounters smooth transition, with options to allow nearby players to join in on the players' side and assist.  They could have done a lot of things.  They did not.  Instead, they stuck to the most basic formula possible.

Oh, and keep in mind it IS subscription based, tho they DO offer a discount if you limit yourself to 1 character (and since you can freely change between all the classes I see no reason for needing alts).


So my final score:

Atmosphere: 9/10
Graphics: 7/10
Sound: 7/10

Gameplay: WoW/10

Substitute in your own number for that based on how much you personally enjoy WoW-style combat.  For me it's a 1/10 on that, and since combat makes up a majority of the gameplay, whether hunting for levels, killing for quests, running a dungeon or raid, if you can't love the combat you can't love the game. I would maybe return to this for the sake of just hanging out with my friends if it were free to play, but I refuse to spend another penny on a game that cannot keep me entertained during the majority of its gameplay.

If you enjoy WoW and all of its clones, I do highly recommend this game to you.  If you're like me and are bored to tears of the same system being duplicated over and over for over a decade, stay away.

reviewText:
Staying true to the Final Fantasy name, Final Fantasy XIV delivers very great gameplay as Square Enix's 2nd Final Fantasy MMORPG.

It's pretty, now supporting a DirectX 11 client, with improved Tesselation and water effects, causes the game to look slightly better than DirectX 9, which the game originally supported.

It's very well optimized for PC. I run a i7 4790K and a GTX 970 with 16gb Ram. Not only can I run this game in 1080p maxed out at 60fps, I can also stream it with those same settings at a 3.5 bitrate, and my computer doesn't cripple in performance.

It has quite a variety. Final Fantasy XIV boasts multiple classes you can pick from. A wide diversity, that is simplified for dungeon play into 3 categories: Healer, DPS, and Tank. Players will be required to form parties with the minimal 1x Healer, 2x DPS, and 1x Tank. You can't just run in a dungeon and expect to solo the entire thing, you need your party members.

The only downside to this game is, you need friends. So you better know people who are already in the game to join, or go alone and make friends on your own. If you don't have anyone to play with, I can't really justify the monthly subscription fee of $13~15.

Me? I'm here for the catgirl customization options.

reviewText:
CuteFish Review: Longish review, pro/con list, closing thoughts. Just skip ahead if you don't like reading! :3

FFXIV: A Realm Reborn is a game that aimed to polish and refine the 'WoW-era' MMO instead of hamfisting in a slightly different spin of the genre. A story based leveling system (at first) that leads into a content rich MMO that has appeal to, quite literraly, any form of player who likes the genre. Very challenging group-based endgame PvE, good PvP, and an abundance of 'things to do' that makes for a very gratifying time sink.

Aesthetically, the game has a clean look similar to the other current-gen Final Fantasy games. It runs rather well on my machine and pretty decently on lower end machines, but it's definitely an art style that loses quite a lot of its charm when you start setting graphical settings to 'low'.

The combat system is the standard tab-targetting most of us are likely accustumed to but actually at a slower pace. The game has a 2.5 second global cooldown between abilities. Early on, this feels incredibly slow (because it is) but later on it feels much more meticulous since each ability use is quite a time commitment. I feel much more weight to use the 'right' ability than any other MMO I've ever played, and a big part of using the 'right' ability lies in understanding the fight. This makes the game far less 'go through your rotation based' and just thought-provoking enough to make you forget you're even waiting 2.5 seconds between spells and it's wonderful.

The game has a unique system in which 100% of the content the game contains can be completed on one single character. Every class, job, craft, quest, etc can be completed on one character to the point where there is genuinelly no practical reason to ever make a second. This makes for a unique attachment to that one special character who will likely be with you from beginning to end. All classes (including crafts) can be changed at a whim (outside of dungeons and PvP) by simply changing your weapon. You're given a bonus 25 slots per gear slot to hold every single piece and an easy 'gear set' system to quickly swap between entire sets of gear for your variety of classes.

FFXIV has a pretty decent story with likeable characters and hit-or-miss voice acting. The only major complaint is how you're supposed to be the 'hero of light'... along with all the other thousands of players on your server. Even looking past that, it delivers a classical Final Fantasy adventure that hits all the right notes possible in the MMO setting.

Leveling is rather easy and straightforward; but at the same time allows for an impressive amount of freedom in how you want to go about it at all. Your first class/job will primarily follow the main story line supplemented by FATEs (randomly spawned group content in the world) and dungeon queues to level at a solid pace. The pacing was excellent and was a rather mild curve in the time between levels as you progress. Part of what makes leveling great is that after progressing a little bit into the game you gain access to 'Duty Roulette', which allows you to queue for a random dungeon and upon completetion, receive a tremendous surge in xp on top of the already solid dungeon xp. This allows people on time restraints to level at a very reasonable pace as all you really need is about 35 minutes. After having one max level class, all future classes gain +100% xp to almos everything, partly because they dont get the main story and partly to speed you along.

This is an MMO with a definite PvE focus, as the dungeons are execellently crafted progression of difficulty from the start to the end. A complaint does lie in the first set of dungeons aquired very early on as they were very devoid of mechanics and give a bad impression of future content. Lategame PvE offers a multitude of challenge tiers to accomadate what you as a player are looking to do. Duty Finder raids, unlike other MMO counterparts, don't offer an easy mode, and its nice to see the game respect the playerbase by demanding a minimum skill requirement to start getting your hands on decent gear pieces.

A special mention should go out to this games crafting system. While earlier I mentioned this game has a strong sense of polish to the genre, this area was given a revamp compared to virtually every other MMO with a focus of creating depth, choices, strategy, and a purpose. The crafts are actually classes with their own gear avaiable to them to boast the crafting potentional. Every craft class has their unique spells used during the hard-to-describe act of actually crafting, which plays almost like a classical turn based game balancing many factors such as the progress towards actually finishing the item vs the actual quality of it, among other factors. Craft classes also have certain abilities that benefit other crafts, encouraging you to do them all even if you only really want to use one. Honestly if you've ever wanted to go hard on some crafts, this is DEFINITELY the game to do it.

On a final note, this game has the best soundtrack and the most cinematic, epic bosses in any MMO I've played. I genuinelly don't want to really spoil any of by showing you, but it's pretty freaking great.

Pros
+ Single-character system builds strong bond with your player character.
+ Content that will appeal to any audience that already likes the MMO genre, and many newcomers (are there still any?)
+ Combat that requires some actual mental usage regarding what abilities you're using.
+ Best MMO on a console (but you're reading this on steam...)
+ Great story that blends into the game almost seamlessely.
+ Heavily teamwork-based group PvE content.
+ The content updates are HUGE. The latest one (3.2) required a hefty time investment just to read through all the patch notes.
+ Heavy timesink game based around progressing the overall state of your character rather than locking you behind time/grindgates. Always something to do~
+ Most fun I've had crafting in an MMO to date.
+ Amazing soundtrack that makes bosses feel larger than life. Many bosses have multiple songs, with one even having 5 whole songs. FIVE SONGS!
+ System in place to help new players learn the game, from decent tutorials to a whole network of matching new players with highly experienced ones for guidance.
+ Amazing community from my personal experience.

Cons
- There's a large divide between emptier and fuller servers. Definitely do your research before commiting to a server.
- Early game dungeons are pretty awful.
- Endgame gear/stat choices for each job is very linear. This is lessened since you can play all 13 classes on 1 character.
- The gathering classes are really runescape-y in their grind... but I mean theres not much you can do with collecting rocks.
- Some of the voice acting in English sucks. Some of it is pretty great. But mostly mediocre.
- When you reach level 50 theres a 100 quest slog to get through before you can start the Heavensward (50->60 content.) It's pretty rough, not gonna lie. At least you only have to do it on one character!

Closing thoughts: This game is epitome of taking the fundamentals of a game type and making them perfect. If you're feeling a little burned out by games like WoW or any of its plentiful clones, it may be time to give FFXIV a whirl. If you're just looking for a really comfy game to play and always have stuff to do when you log on, this game is great for that. If you want that classic hardcore PvE content found in the earlier days of WoW, this game delivers on that front too!

Overall rating: 9/10

reviewText:
If you're a fan of MMORPGs, Final Fantasy XIV is the perfect game for you. Though it is a subscription based game, as of this review, it has surpassed many Free-to-Play MMORPGs out in the sea of games already with a blend of certain ingredients.

Starting off by making your character, you have multiple choices of races you can become. From a regular human, a midget, cat people, elves and even huge peoples. There are many options to personalize your character if you choose to do so, such as eyes(heterochromia), tattoos, and even hair highlights(which was a first to me), You might be wondering if this is when you choose your class now, and you're right. To my amazement, your one character can master ALL the classes within the game. All you need to do is simply reach a certian level and you can accept to join all the class guilds. After that all you do is switch weapons and become that class.(Amazing right?) After you perfect your character, you are immediately thrown into the beautiful world we know as Eorzea.

Putting the amazing transition SE has went with the end of FFXI to FFXIV aside, the story of your character begins in a slow pace. Most people will be put off by this slow beginning, but the story does start to get interesting to the point you want to learn more about it. Anymore information and it might end up in spoilers, so you decide whether to pay attention to the story or blitz through quests exclusively for experience towards your character.

The last thing I'd like to mention is about the dungeon system. You have finders which will automatically find you dungeons/parties, this can be a good or bad thing. So far from my experience, the community is nice to new players and will help you out and then we have some that are not so......nice. Either way, you can decide to use this or play with your friends within a party up to 8 people. As you progress through the game, you'll unlock more harder and interesting dungeons in which your team of friends can have fun  participating in. You might be wondering if there is anything rewarding from doing these. Besides receiving entertainment, drops such as weapons or armor might be a eye candy for your character. Another big thing would be the music. The music in this game is superb.

TL:DR - Buy or at least try the game(free trial is up to 2 weeks). You will most likely enjoy the game and music and join the community, if not....at least you tried it....

logged 571 hours over a couple of months at the time of writing this. Which doesn't seem like a lot but the way I play games (play for a few hours, stop, play, stop) it's a lot of time to dedicate to one game.
I haven't played an FF game I enjoyed since X. That is, until XIV came out. I've played a lot of MMOs including WoW and none of them held my interest for long. In FFXIV there are a lot of things to do and the community is the most enjoyable one I've encountered.

One of the things I enjoy the most is that you don't have to stick to one class. On my  main I started off as a Lancer and instead of remaking and loosing all that time you can simply go pick up a new class (which gets upgraded to a job once you complete the level 30 quest). If you get sick of your character appearance you can use a potion that you get as part of the vetran rewards to change everything about them (or you can buy one). If you're just sick of their hair/makeup changing that is as simple as coughing up 2k gil for a makeover. (which is nothing at all later on, especially if you craft)
Speaking of crafting, that's a feature that held my interst for hours. It's rewarding, although often expensive. In addition to making weapons/armor/clothing for your character you can also make furniture if you have a house, which you can buy personally or by joining a guild called a Free Company that has one. The only gripe I have is super long DPS queue times but that's less the games fault so much as the fact that I play DPS mainly.

It will trash your life and suck up your time. 10/10.

The first MMO I played and really got into was WoW. I quit playing it for good about half a year before Pandaria's release. Edit: Roughly 2000 hours after initially writing this review, I can still say I am completely in love with this game. An absolute must buy! If you're not convinced, there's a trial you can find of FFXIV here on Steam which gives you a little taste of how the game is... sadly enough, it gives you a taste of the early game. The weakest part of FFXIV. The endgame is where it shines, but you'll have to put in more time for that! Again, I can't recommend this game enough!

Edit: Another edit, it's now been over 4000 hours and the first expansion (Heavensward) has released, and it is a great addition to an already great game. I really can not urge you enough to at least give the trial a go -despite low level being the weakest part of the game, as I mentioned in my previous edit-.

-Ciaran Dango & Sena Tempus, Moogle

reviewText:
I have played Final Fantasy for a Very Long Time. Final Fantasy is not so much a videogame as a feel of a videogame, a specific set of familiarities and tones that amass into a notion of strange particularity. It’s hard to separate the act of playing Final Fantasy from our perception of what a game like Final Fantasy is: its look, its feel, the sound of a familiar melody at the title screen that tells you yes, this is Final Fantasy, and everything is going to be okay. Final Fantasy is not a game, but a smell, a memory, a compulsion.

I have been playing Final Fantasy 14: A Realm Reborn a lot, to my own surprise. This new rendition of a previous disaster which I have not personally experienced is seamlessly, indulgently playable. It is a game of unrelenting maximalism— every single Final Fantasy mainstay is hurled at you indiscriminately with reckless abandon— while at the same time being totally relaxing. It’s like plummeting into the ocean only to realize that it is the exact same temperature as your body. Unlike something like Call of Duty, which is equally big and playable but requires muscles tensed and brain on edge, FF14 washes over you in a warm crystalline blue glow of fantasy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

I played FF14 while catching up with a friend on Skype. I planned a ♥♥♥♥ing camping trip while playing it. Final Fantasy just occurs, if you let it. Do you know what else does this? Evil.

You can play Final Fantasy forever, if you want to.

reviewText:
This game is not for everyone (even though it probably should be). Short summary opinion is at the end for those that want to skip reading a longer opinion.

The quests in this game are much more diverse than in many other ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes. They range from investigation style quests, to NPC interaction quests, to your cookie cutter fetch and kill quests and more. Some require you to run dungeons and other require you to take part in mini raid style battles on the world map (you dont need a party to participate in these).

It needs to be understood that this game is extremely heavy on storyline content to the point that some may feel like they are reading an interactive book rather than playing an MMO. This means quite a bit of single player questing and even single player instanced battles as part of many questlines. For some this may be a source of irritation but for people that are familiar with the Final Fantasy brand, this is an amazing chance to become engrossed in the realm of Eorzea.

If you are planning on playing this MMORPG just to skip every dialogue and run to every quest mark, you will probably start feeling either annoyed or confused at what is going on with the quests and frustration may result from that. This is because the main story quests play a large part in character progression in terms of unlocking areas but they are also very detail oriented in terms of conveying a personal story to the player rather than simply grinding out exp to level up.

The storylines, both main and side, reflect some of the best writing to come out of a Final Fantasy game in a very long time and you can very easily forget you are even playing an MMO at times.

There is a rather large drawback however, depending on your point of view...  This game demands that it's players EARN practically everything.
You are NOT given a mount for free when you hit a certain level, you have to meet certain conditions to earn the right to ride a mount or stick with cheap taxi mounts until you do.
You are NOT given access to your full ability tree as you level up and instead must take part in quests / storyline unique to your class in order to earn additional abilities and even a job class unique to your base class.
You are NOT given access to dungeons in the game until you either follow the main story quests to the point they are unlocked for story reasons or until you find the side quests that unlock them for story reasons.

The list goes on but you probably get the idea... things in this game are earned through hardwork, not through mindless grinding or by getting carried on the coattails of a high level friend that can just shower nice items on you (but that second one would still probably help alot if you are that lucky).

The game is great, The story is amazing (both powerfully dramatic and enjoyable comical at times) and the gameplay mechanics are enough to challenge even seasoned MMO vets in the level 50+ dungeons and trial fights.

reviewText:
I love this game.  I think it's one of the best video games I've ever played.  It's weird, though, because it's not a game that comes without a load of the problems typical of MMOs.  (This is totally my opinion here, so if you're a reader who loves everything about MMORPGs and you disagree, that's totally fine.)  For long stretches of the leveling game, combat can be extremely dull depending on a variety of things: what job you've chosen, whether or not you have any companions (e.g. solo questing as a gladiator/paladin is going to be feel pretty slow when it takes you a moment or two to kill anything), and you're going to be sitting in queue after queue waiting for your turn in the dungeons.  Combat for some jobs is not very interesting until you're level 50 or 60 and you have access to dungeons and raids that will test your skills (often with boss mechanics that seem weird or even overwhelming at first, but are satisfying to pull off as a group overcoming a unique challenge), and that's an investment I'd want anyone to be aware of when getting into something like this.  You'll spend a lot of time pressing a few keys in sequence while you whittle down the HP of this or that monster.

Thankfully, most of the queues are pretty short and there are tools for getting people together for something even if the Duty Finder isn't pulling together a party for you.  And there's plenty to do while you wait: keep on questing, do some gathering or crafting, play Triple Triad.  Very importantly, for me, it's a world that feels good to hang out in.  The first and larger paragraph up there probably seems overly negative for a game I'd recommend to others, but here's so much that I enjoy about Final Fantasy present here — my bard's equipment is glamoured to look like early FF character designs by Yoshitaka Amano, and there's tons of armor (and other designs) in the game that support this style and atmosphere.  It is a legit as heck hangout/comfy game.  The challenging (hardcore raiding) stuff is there if you want it.

Just some thoughts here; not really a full review or an attempt to convince anyone to play.  It's my jam, tho.  I may come and go, and frankly I'm extremely relieved that it's a game I only want to play for a few months at a time between extended breaks, but when I'm into it... well, I'm pretty into it.
