reviewText:
Realm Reborn is a sequel to the previously released Final Fantasy XIV, which wasn’t received very well, and this is even conveniently explained in the game’s plot: there’s an apocalypse which ravages the whole realm and begins a new era. Personally I hadn’t played the previous game but this sequel is said to offer significant improvements over the original across the board, it's essentially an entirely redesigned game of its own.

The plot is fairly generic save the world kind of stuff: you are an adventurer brought into one of the game’s three big city-states with a special ability to attune to crystals which hold some great ability to hold off evil. You perform tasks for the city-states and eventually rise to become an envoy between them and even serve them. Similar to single-player games, the main plot and many of the other quests are filled with cutscenes, and in the main story’s case, the significant ones are also voiced. It’s all easy to follow and they’ve tried to put a bit of story into everything, for instance all of the game’s class guilds have a storyline of their own that advances as you gain levels and do guild quests.

However this kind of plot is well suited for MMO and something as complex as Final Fantasy XIII’s super messy plot obviously wouldn’t work here. Rising in guild ranks and joining armies feels like an accomplishment, and you get treated to far more heroic stuff like taking on massive primals (think summons from previous Final Fantasy titles) rather fast. The game overall plays much like a singleplayer game story wise: the story is focused on your personal character and many plot advancing quests have certain “duty” sections that can only be completed with your own character, such as taking on a boss battle. This can be reversed too in some cases: some boss battles and dungeons instead put you in a party with others. Most of the game can be soloed if you want, but the option to do stuff in a party is totally there too, you’ll only ever be separated for brief periods at a time.

This focus on your own character is what sets the game apart from other MMOs in my opinion and makes the game more interesting. The cutscenes are also no worse quality than in singleplayer FF titles and the game’s graphics and particularly animation are fantastic. All characters are lively animated and seeing your character pull off all kinds of stuff like stupid faces in cutscenes is really fun and involving. The game is also really well optimized, running on a large variety of systems and even having its own preset settings for laptops for instance that take your specs into account. The user interface in the game is really good too, super easy to use and slick looking, I was never at a loss to find something.

Gameplay is similar to other MMO titles and the difficulty level is really good across the board, you will be challenged at every level and you can always find more dangerous or easier opponents and quests. As a nice twist your character can be literally any class in the game – you can use and level any one class at a time, provided you have joined their guild, and certain class abilities can also be used by other classes. For instance, Gladiators that have leveled Conjurer can cast Cure, which they normally wouldn’t have access to, so cross-classing a bit is encouraged and even required to get Jobs (specialized mid/late-game classes) later on. To swap a class you just swap to a different gear preset, which you can create lists of. At the most basic level you just need to change a weapon to switch to another class.

The game is easy to get into as well, there’s a 15 day free trial that offers leveling of a single character up to level 20, but you can cross-class him/her as much as you like, and it’s definitely enough to get a good look at the game. The free trial is best played with a friend that already owns the game though, because you cannot set up your own parties in it, but other subscribed players can invite you to theirs. Marketplace and trading functions are limited but otherwise there’s no significant restrictions. The game is available as a digital download on the website and on Steam, as well as on PS3 and PS4 on the consoles, the multiplayer is cross-platform, and new buyers of the game automatically get 30 free game days. Steam users will also be happy to know that the monthly subscription can be paid with just Steam wallet money, assuming you also bought the game from Steam.

TL;DR

It's great. Don't compare it to Square Enix's other new FF games. It's a traditional ♥♥♥♥♥♥me with Final Fantasy flavor and one well designed one at that. I enjoy it tons more than the recent main series FF games. And I wrote this review originally for something else in mind, if you're wondering why it's so long and detailed. :P Give it a chance, it deserves more PC Steam players. And, it has a ton of content in a large world. I still feel like I've barely scratched the surface of what it has to offer so far at the moment of writing.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy 14 is one of those very rare games that embodies wholly what you look for in the MMO genre. I started my experience back in the middle of 2015 and since then enjoyed, almost every step (aside Titan EX). FFXIV caters to the needs of many kinds of players those that heed the call of combat and those that want to craft and relax online. It has open ends on all parts of the scale making sure you have lots to do, without being pressured to do it.

The key points for this game include:
Playing everysingle class on one character, allows for diversity at times when you need it without taking away your efforts.
Great socialisiation, it targets well how people can interract with each other online as their substitute self-
Amazing customisation, by god is the customisation good, go a head make your character, you will never find someone that looks like you.
Intricate story, though it has had a tendancy to get a little dry at time the primary campaign which takes you through the levels is incredibly enjoyable and the story itself is well written and crafted, though watch yourself if you really hate politics.
The combat and leveling,.. the key point of most MMOs, FFXIV has it set to a T. Everything is balanced and created so 'Jobs' can fit in with one another. I my played Archer until I could reach the Bard Job. This primarily made me the support DPS in all dungeons. Whilst each healer and each tank has their own specific uses which each and every ability cater to. This isn't really something I can explain with words so I suggest looking up a few YouTube videos on the classes and Jobs.
Lastly the dungeons or Duties as they are called. The main focus of this game as a whole is to prep yourself for Duties which are dungeon crawls, boss battle trials and Raids. All are extremely fun and hold the entirity of the main game within them outside of the storyline. Each dungeon is unique with bosses and units your team have to take down co-operatively, Trials toss you up against one of the big guys which have diverse fighting mechanics you need to learn and master as a team to take down and Raids, well, we all know what raids are...

My final scores for FFXIV are as follows
Score  Visuals and landscaping  8.5/10  Soundtrack  9/10  Gameplay  9/10  Controls  9.5/10  Dialogue, quests and story  7.5/10  Social aspects and self customisation  10/10  OVERALL  9/10

reviewText:
The original version of Final Fantasy XIV was, to say, a disasterous release from Square Enix. Problems from glitches, bad economies between the players and NPCs and being flat-out unfinished.

Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn (or version 2.0 onwards) fixes so many of the problems and the game itself has good controls, an easy-to-use interface and HUD and beautiful sceneries and locations (with areas like Coerthas having been altered altogether from the original version). Each class has their own advantages and disadvantages and unique abilities that they learn upon levelling up or completing class-exclusive quests. Upon learning an ability that belongs to a specfic class, for example, Raging Strikes from the Archer, it can be used by other classes providing they're within level range to use it.

The game offers many quests and dungeons as the story progresses, with new dungeons and harder variants of the bosses unlockable post-story (as of ver. 2.1 onwards). If you're a completionist-type of player, you will have plenty of things to collect and complete throughout the game.

You will have to pay a subscription fee for this game, but for each period of subscription, you will be rewarded exclusive items, better known as Veteran Rewards. If you have a friend who wants to give the game a go, but doesn't want to spend anything yet, the Recruit-a-friend campaign allows them a 14-day free trial to see if it suits their fancy, furthermore, if your friend subscribes, you and your friend will get rewards only obtainable through this campaign.

Old and new players will find plenty to do in this game, and if you're looking for a good time in an MMO I would definitely recommend Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn.

reviewText: Strikes a very satisfying balance between RPG and action game. Classes and skills themselves are very simple, much moreso than ones you'd often find in other MMOs. The simplicity allows for the player to focus harder on individual fights rather on stats and builds. This means that, assuming you're properly geared, you have only yourself to blame for death or messing up. You didn't put an extra point in a bad stat, you didn't level a bad skill, you just messed up, and the next step is learning how not to do the same thing again. Or you lagged. Titan HM/EX, every time.\nMechanic memorization may not be everyone's cup of tea, but in my opinion it is much better and more satisfying to clear a boss or a raid because you knew what to do, when and how, rather than because you're a big bad min/max'd dude with perfect stats and a perfect skill build. You get to where you are through practice, through learning, through experiencing. You can't just invest a bunch of time/gil into BiS gear and expect to do good at everything if you haven't tried it yet, and that's why I really love this game.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy XIV is an MMO that takes the common tropes of many others, polishes them up and delivers content on a fairly regular basis with an open producer and a lot of community involvement. With MMOs being largely community driven, the fact that the Final Fantasy XIV team is willing to share as much and as often as they do (going so far as to describe the problems they had in the original launch of the game and how they worked on them) is a breath of fresh air.

The failure of Final Fantasy XIV Online was something of a reality check and with the two years spent redeveloping the game we now have a well written story surrounded with an excellent series of challenges to keep people busy with. The game is visually impressive and runs many times better than it's failed predecessor. Combat is at a fair pace with a number of different classes that you can change to on the fly just by changing your primary weapon.

While Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is primarily a PvE game, the development team has done an excellent job at bringing in content in a timely manner, providing for quality-of-life adjustments, and has been extremely effective in documenting and implementing a lot of the playerbase's wishes.

If you're looking for an MMO, Final Fantasy XIV isn't a bad one to look at. With it's entry price being half that of other new MMOs, and the subscription offerings being more flexible than others, the game is not only well cared for, but hard to beat for it's price of entry.

reviewText:
This is certainly a decent MMO, one of the better ones currently available, however, I find I can't recommend it.

I really wanted to love this game, and the crafting was really great...at least until you got into higher level stuff.  It was with great sorrow that I realized that the higher tiers of crafting had some bizarre, invisible-except-for-certain-times-of-day mechanic putting my happy gathering spree to an immediate, screeching halt.  I understand the need to make things rare in order to maintain the economy, but seriously?  Faced with the choice of standing, waiting for hours for a single node to spawn or buying it from the market, buying it from the market seems a much better choice, at least, until you see the prices, and realise that it would take you just as many hours of harvesting regular things to sell to afford one.  I suppose this is 'balance' but it certainly wasn't fun, and crushed my hopes as a crafter.

The game will also 'force' you to participate in queue-for-group dungeon content to advance your main story quest, and I found unless you queued as tank or healer, you'd be waiting sometimes hours for a group (which may or may not even stay together to finish the dungeon!) just to advance your main, storyline quest.  I eventually made it to the end, but after that I was left with just a sense of overall disillusionment.  Add that to the pointlessness of the crafting at higher tiers, and well...

As I said, it is one of the better MMOs out there, but I don't feel it has anything for the 'long haul' - unless you fancy queueing for groups and sitting afk at node spawn points for months on end, which ultimately killed it for me.  Perhaps if you have unlimited playtime to do the time-sink routine it'd be worth a play.

reviewText:
After experiencing all there is to offer, I can't honestly recommend this to someone looking for a faithful paid MMO in its current state. Sure, it's pretty fun for a while, but it gets too demanding and monotonous to enjoy playing in the long run, unless that's what you're into. Heavensward, the $40 expansion, is a well played joke. Multiplying the exp requirement for leveling and making you hike across massive maps* makes up more of this expansion's playtime than actual content. Significant updates are few and far between.

*Flying isn't unlocked for the area until you've activated every Aether Current across the map and awarded via quests, and by that time you're moving on to the next area anyway, where the process repeats.

TL;DR : A fantastic aesthetic, amazing soundtrack, accessible combat system and engaging story masks a life draining waiting simulator plagued with bad dev choices and Chinese RMT bots.

I'd like to hear from those who still stand by this game, as I can't fathom why.

10/10 Would delete and restore character again.

reviewText:
What is it? Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn (From here on out called FF14 Online) is an MMORPG Fantasy game set with the Final Fantasy Universe.

What is it NOT? FF14 Online is not your typical Final Fantasy Game. Its an Online MMO, which means you MUST have an internet connection to play. There is also a monthly fee ($14.99USD) to play, so please consider this before diving into this game, as it could become very expensive and a waste of money for those of you that do not play at least once a day.

Graphics:  FF14 Online has some of the best graphics for an MMO I have seen in a long time. Everything is crisp, framerates are smooth, and the cutscenes are not like previous entries (Extremely higher detailed than in-game. Yeah, Im looking at you, Final Fantasy 12!) There are multiple options in system settings you can mess with to achieve the highest Framrate you can. Even lower end systems can play this fairly well without too much of a hit to visual quality.

Gameplay:  The game plays as you would expect any major MMO to: You begin by creating your character. Changing their appearence, race, class/job, etc. Do not fret too much about picking a starter class. Unlike most ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes, FF14 Online allows you to eventually learn any and all classes/jobs. Most of which have crossover abilities! (A Gladiator using curative spells? An Archer with black magic? Yes! You CAN do it!)

Does it have Single-Player Mode? FF14, as stated before, is an MMORPG, meaning there is no true single-player mode available. While this is a fact, most of the main storyline can be completed solo, with the exception of certain dungeons. There is also a lot of solo content for you to play, if that is your thing. But you get the true enjoyment out of this game with the group system, Free Companies, and many other vsrious social forms.

Do I recommend this game? I give this game a definite Yes"! If you are into games that give you the most bang for your buck

reviewText:
This is easily the best MMO I've played in years. The graphics are beautiful, the character creation is very in-depth, and it actually feels like you're involved in the combat instead of just sitting there tapping buttons until you fall asleep. The crafting system is unique and fun (albeit frustrating sometimes), too. If you get bored of questing, dungeoning, and crafting, you can go play games and race chocobos at the Golden Saucer, if you're so inclined. You'll never run out of things to do in this game.

And if you're a roleplayer like me, Balmung has a huge and varied roleplay community--you're more than likely to find what you're looking for, no matter what your RP style is.

The only thing I don't like about the game is the character creation restrictions. If a server is overpopulated, you can't make a new character on it, and have to wait until the populated is a bit lower, which is usually really early in the morning (if you're in America). This is a huge problem on Balmumg, which really stinks if you're looking for an RP server. Other than that, though, this game is great and totally worth the $15 a month.

reviewText:
Once upon a time, there was a game called Final Fantasy XIV.  It was awful.  People noticed, first, then Square Enix noticed.  After a bunch of changes to everything we got a brand new game: FFXIV:ARR.

ARR is, first, a complete game.  There's content everywhere, the combat feels great, the soundtrack is awesome.  The crafting system is unusual in the best possible way - it's instanced to your character, so no more resource-stealing!

The downside is, it's a very, very immature MMORPG.  While the raids and dungeons are well thought-out, other fights are less so.  The storyline group boss fights against the Espers give no loot.  What's worse, the game really doesn't 'start' until you reach very high levels, so enjoy questing and grinding...which take a long time, and aren't well-paced at all, for a game that truly 'begins' at the endgame.

PROS:
A FF MMO that actually feels like a core Final Fantasy game!
Beautiful music - particularly the 'Wild West' Chocobo theme!
Interesting game mechanics
Good quest writing, good translation.
Instanced resource collection (tradeskills)
You only need one character - anyone can be everything!
Excellent endgame PvE experience.
Frequent updates with new endgame content
CONS:
The game doesn't truly start until the level cap; most of the game is a glorified single-player mode.
Huge amounts of RNG involved in the crafting system.
Nearly no PvP to speak of.  If you hate PvP, this is a PRO, but I love PvP.
Main storyline boss fights don't give loot (!!!???)
Runs very poorly on older hardware - if you have an older system, upgrade before buying this game.
Final Verdict: Make sure your system can handle this game before you buy it, but do, it is worth your money...if you don't care about PvP.  If you're a PvP gamer, there's other games, but this game will hold you for a month easily.

reviewText:
So after almost putting 1000 hours into the game, here is the lay down.

- First MMO that I've actually put effort into.
- Easy to get into and the EXP curve is not harsh. (Doing the main quest alone, with some side quest and you can reach the Level limit no problem) (Leveling up other classes though takes time)
- I'm enjoying the story, as do many others, though if you don't want to, it is all skippable.
- You only need to make one character because that one character can be any-class as you can switch on the fly. First you must get to level 15 to one of the classes then you can switch to whatever else you want if you don't feel like it suits your role you want to be. Or you can be like me and level up all the classes. (I main Monk)
- Want to just be a crafter? There is that too and they make money (gil persay) if you join a good FC willing to support the mats (materials you need).
- End-game content is very captivating if you want to raid. There are many raid groups always looking to fill spots if that is what you seek. It is enjoyable and worthwhile. Trust me, it takes a lot of wipes (sometimes one or if your raid team is excellent, only one try), but its feel good.
- Great community
- Square Enix will not disappoint. They always have something awesome planned for this.
- Heavensward Expansion!

Would highly recommend trying it out first. It might not be for everyone, but if you like Final Fantasy (and this game as soo many tibbits to its other titles, ex. Void Ark (FF5) , Crystal Tower (FF3), Gilgamesh, and others), you will enjoy this MMO.

Final Fantasy 14: A Realm Reborn is the 14th installment in the long running Final Fantasy series (No ♥♥♥♥). However, this is not your usual FF game. This is a paid subscription based MMO, similar to World of Warcraft, Black Desert Online, etc. The game version currently available is 3.1, with patch 3.2 coming soon.

GAMEPLAY
FF14 is very different from your usual MMO, because of the way it handle's it's class setup. When you begin the game and create your character, you decide on what your starting class will be. This affects your starting location, and sets the main game into motion. However, once you complete the tutorial" quests you can essentially live your life how you want to. The game doesnt force you to continue the main quest at any point

reviewText:
Where to begin?
First off I am a huge Final Fantasy fan, I own and have played through every FF game to date. My alias is Mog and I typically go by Moogle Assasin7. That being said, this is my SECOND favorite FF title to date. Don't get me wrong though, I do have some gripes about this game which is why it's only my second fav.

What you need to know about this game is that you have to buy it and it has a subscription (BOTH are required to play). I didn't realize this until my free trial ran out. Very dissapointed that they left that tidbit out of the discription. However, I still play because its awesome.

Next is the game itself. Very repetitive... you tend to do a lot of the same stuff over and over. The trick is to mix up your game play and switch up your focus. There is a massive amount of story and there is always something to do. Voice acting is great. Plus the devs are constantly adding new content, which helps keep you engaged. Community is great, I have yet to have a problem with a single person. It's easy to drop in and out. This is nothing like FFXI, you CAN actually progress through the story line and you'll do it almost completely solo.

I use a midgrade laptop that runs on windows 8.1 and it handles fine. (usually around 11fps) I know that isn't alot but this game doesn't require much. Biggest drain on fps is the hunts.

Bottom line 9/10 for massive amout of content, easy to learn, hard to master, great story but repetitive. Totally worth the 15 bucks a month. Highly recommend.

GAMEPLAY:
Like most MMOs, you have the holy trinity of dps, healer and tanks. In this game they are divided into classes, which can further specialise into jobs. Cross class skills are used, so lets say I'm a White Mage at level 60, I can use cross class to access some skills from other classes/jobs I've leveled. Classes/Jobs are also handled differently. Your character can switch between any of the classes/jobs as they get unlocked, allowing you to completely change your playstyle should you choose to in the future. There's even classes like Fishing, Blacksmithing or Alchemist if you want to work the markets, or help your Free Company build an airship! Gameplay is like most MMOS, except it can get quite challenging as you get to a higher level. IMO this game has some of the hardest content from any MMO out there. reviewText:
The graphics on this game are amazing. It also scales well across old and new technology.

I am a die-hard WoW fan, and will probably always play it on-and-off until it ends, but this game might be the first major MMO to catch my attention. It all just works. The first few levels are a bit disorientating, but after level 5 it starts to make sense. The community is also young (as the game is new) but very polite and helpful.

There's a decent variety of classes to start off with, and those who hate alts will love that they can switch classes just by changing weapons after a certain point in the game. (Level 15?) WIth some hybrid classes only being available after you level two individual classes to 30/15 respectively. There's almost a guarentee of many many more classes coming over from the previous FFXI title. Ideally it would flesh out every primary class with two specialization choices-- like how Arcanist must choose between Summoner or Scholar. Classes famous from XI include: Samurai, Black Knight, Corsair, Theif, Red Mage, and Blue Mage.

So far quests are varied and interesting, the enviroments are vibrant, and the world feels alive. I have not experienced any lag client or server side.

If you like classic Final Fantasy, you'll love this game. It's a very solid title and worth a shot.

reviewText:
I picked this up to give it a shot, having heard that the newer version was far improved over the original 1.0 release, and man am I happy I did. The game is gorgeous, entertaining, and does a fantastic job of pulling you into the narrative, and making you care about the npc characters. The ability to level all the classes on one character is a blessing and a curse, but overall I like the way it feels.

Biggest downsides for me are the lack of chat bubbles, and the need to grind xp to finish the main story/cap your character once you surpass level 35. There's also a fair bit of gold spamming, and having to type out a ticket to report it every time is very tedious, especially compared to WoW's one button report spam feature.

Overall, very happy with my purchase, and the ability to pay for subscription via the steam wallet. It's well worth $30 to give this a try and see if it's right for you!

reviewText:
My original review was SO LONG that it became a novel…
That soon became a trilogy…
That was eventually released on blu-ray DVD.
…
That’s how much I love this game

tl;drThe game comes with a free month, which is more than enough time to give it a try. Despite the lackluster fighting IMO (read below), it doesn't detract from the overall gameplay. FFXIV is an absolutely gorgeous and vast world, and one of the best subscription MMO's I've played. I would recommend this game to any of my friends.

---

COMMUNITY:FREE-to-play MMOs are like highschool.
You’re often surrounded by people who could care less about you or the community, and only a select few people who do care.

One of the biggest reasons I play any subscription based MMO is for the community.

SUBSCRIPTION based MMOs are like university. You’re at a hub where like-minded people gather, who have paid for their entrance, and in doing so will most likely try their best to thrive; the only way to do so is to become apart of the community.
My first day on the server I was invited to a free company (a lesser form of a guild), and I was chatting up my FC mates like no tomorrow. We shared stories, got to know each other a little bit, and some of the max level players came out to help me quest for fun (they even gave me a free pet). We also went to the FC house and chilled in a hot tub, at which point we began to /dance naked without equipment. Needless to say, I felt like the community was incredible.

reviewText:
Honestly my favorite modern MMO. I've put countless hours into it and still find it endlessly enjoyable. The classes are all fun and unique, the crafting is active and interesting, and thanks to the job system you can experience everything the game has to offer with a single character.

I took a break after finishing end game and getting all best in slot gear for my main class, but when I came back I found out that there was almost double the endgame content as when I left. This game is ever changing and ever expanding, new content is being added quite regularly, and it's not just new raids or dungeons. Whole new story quests, expanding on the lore, are added extremely often.

I'm going to sum up my feelings in a list of good and bad from my perspective,

******************************************************************************

What's the good:

The combat: It's slower then most other MMOs but that is a benefit, giving you more time to make a choice on what to do next and how it will be effective. It flows naturally and feels satisfying with just the right amount of power. Later in the game a boss fight stops being just a harder monster you need to work through, but instead becomes a kind of dance, each member of your party having their own role on the stage.

The Quests: Yes, they are a lot of fetch quests and breadcrumbs, it's nothing special in the MMO world... But it somehow is. With all the dialog, lore, and the streamlined loot system, the quests in this game somehow transcend the Go here and do this" standard. The first major thing you might notice? The quest givers know damned well what you're there for

reviewText:
I love this game! All the Final Fantasy characters and monsters! You don't need a new character to play a different class/job! The music is amazing! The story quests are easy to track, and put you at the center as the Hero of Light. Everyone is fighting for the same casue, no good vs bad, so you don't have to worry about being in the wrong place and getting smashed by another player.

There is pvp arena's for those who like to. Plenty of things to do, like hunts, treasure maps, the Hildibrand story line, Chocobo racing. Speeking of Chocobo's, you get one early on for a mount, and it doubles as a companion to fight with you.

The Duty finder is helpful to get into instances when your friends or Free Company members are not around. It also looks to other servers to find players, as well as being a cross-platform with the PlayStation version. Thats right, controllers and KB/M playing side by side

Your are rewarded for your total subscription time, no need to pay every month if you don't want to, you still get the rewards when you have meet the amount of days payed (exp. your first 30 days payed earns a reward, you can not play for a year, and when you pay again, you get the 60 days reward. After a few, it starts to take more time between rewards).

Fighting in this game requires you to move to not be hit by mobs attacks. Even as a caster, you must pay attention to what is coming your way, and sometimes it is just a matter of knowing where to stand to get spells off before you have to move again.

Everything in this game looks great, the characters and equipment, mobs and bosses, zones and backdrops, and of course, the cutscenes! Oh and the spells and ability!!

There is even a Limit Break system while in instances. A shared guage that builds up to 3 levels, and the different class groups (exp. casters, healer, tank, dps) have a different limit break. A level 3 healer limit break will raise all dead party members, casters cast meteor. Time it right and save the day!

Crafting, almost forgot crafting! You don't just click a button and wait for a bar to fill. You have skills to use as a crafter. Skill rotation helps determine output quality. Plus quests for your craft, and the gear just for crafting. Some of the crafting gear is also styled around what you are crafting.

Gathering jobs are  miner, botanist, and fisher

Free companies have houses that provide a place to grow crops for cooking or feed for your chocobo, training dummys to practice your rotation, and a few vendors for repairing equipment, buying regents, or just selling junk.

All of these things (and so much more) tie together wonderfully, and give (me at least) a sense of place in the grand scheme of things.
This, compared to one other mmo I played a lot of, is a huge difference. I just didn't feel the other game gave me any drive to do great things" other than to complete a quest
date: or run a instance for the fun of it. I never felt like I was part of the Big Picture. Kind of hard to put into words
recommended: and maybe I just did not play with the "right" players
hoursPlayed: and I never made it to end game raids.\n\nOver all

reviewText:
*tagged as a Drunk Review*

MMOs are incredibly hard to review.

They require a very different consumption model than the one which follows any other game constuct.

As having almost 4000 hours played would imply, I have a deep invesment into the game if, anything, to prove that I have not wasted over three months of my life playing it.

But it is far more enjoyable than any MMO I have played in the last 10 years.

Being able to play one character who can level anything? Godsdamned priceless.

A crafting system that (before Heaven's Ward) rewarded multiclassing? Superb.

Gathering that is wholly necessary to advance crafting returns? Essential to a proper balance of skills and classes.

A variety of class roles and requirements, wholly integral to endgame content? Fascinating and complicated.

This is the MMO that brought me back after nearly 7 years of exile from WoW.

Enjoy it, love it, find solace in the various game design decisions that benefit the solo player and bring so many options to the multi-player.

But don't get too invested in PvP. It is an afterthought that, while moderately balanced, is not nearly as fun and intuitive as the rest of the game is,

Lula Moon, Faerie server, Lv51+ in every job/class available.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy 14: A Realm Reborn is a new version of the original game, just called Final Fantasy 14 Online, which came to be considered a complete failure. The title, available for PS3 and PC, did not disappoint in his recovery and has met the expectations of fans.
Realm Reborn is a very appropriate name for the game, as he was redone from scratch and this is already felt in its first minutes. Not just the game system, but also its history, characters and operation. Even those who were at advanced levels in the previous version here returning from scratch, entirely renovated.

And so resumes the story of Eorzea, where goes the adventure. Entitled to reset characters and a new mythology, the player gradually gets involved in the action and drama lived by this world. Arriving with his hero in a city, out of nowhere, it needs to give their all to be recognized as someone of value.


The character creation system is well done and complete. Even in the PS3, with commands totally focused on the joystick, it is possible to find and not get lost in the confusing menus. The game does not disappoint in this initial step and is quite complete in everything from races options the initial classes, through appearance setting.

The introduction also fulfills its role well, with a story narrated in the third person and scenes breathtaking, setting the stage for what the player must face over the next few hours - and they are many. As a true MMORPG, Final Fantasy 14: A Realm Reborn has a lot of content.

As in any game genre, the evolution of the characters is due to the missions to be accomplished and advanced levels. Here the experience levels are back (remember they are gone in Final Fantasy 13?), Then the progression is natural. At each level, new skills and more news are unlocked, but there are some surprises.

The first is the possibility of moving level with each class available in the game and others that can be enabled. Unlike other online RPGs, it is not necessary to create several characters to test other classes of heroes. Here you can simply decide that tired of being warrior and changing careers, becoming mage or archer. Of course, this will reset the level that chosen profession, but the former remains.

This kind of change only adds personality of A Realm Reborn, striving to be a MMORPG different from the others, even though some follow successful trends - such as own missions. Fortunately the class system works very well, recalling the classic Final Fantasy Tactics at times - after all, many professions require various levels in others and so on, just as you learned in PlayStation 1.

In fact, much in the Realm Reborn seems to have been inspired by previous games in the series. Elements ranging from the class system up to some spells, elements, materials and so on. Overall, the game risks trying to please enough who is long-time fan, although it can be availed by those who favor recently.


We will not lie, the gameplay of Final Fantasy 14: A Realm Reborn fit like a glove to the game. Everything is very well fitted both on the PC, as the PS3. Play on either platform is a rewarding experience, which is even more impressive for console users.

It is worth mentioning that everything works well in DualShock 3 control, and even the PC version is fully compatible with an Xbox 360 control plugged into the computer. Commands are natural, menus can be easily accessed and attacks are activated easily, quickly and accurately, as a struggle requires.


This type of adaptation is played master of Square Enix, since the game can be availed on both platforms with just one account. Unfortunately you have to buy it twice, once on the PC and one on the PS3, to play with them, but later the first month tuition - $ 15 every 30 days - goes for both platforms simultaneously. A nice plus.

In addition, all the characters, friends list and historical are saved in both the PC and the PS3, the online server of the producer. This happens because the game is exclusively online, of course, but there is an advantage in this.

A Realm Reborn has decent graphics to be called a legitimate representative of the Final Fantasy saga. With the right effects jaw-dropping, neat monsters and spells with many special elements, the game does not make ugly, despite the PS3 version lose a little - just a little - the title on the PC.

Another point that stands out are the very cities. Some, at first, are very small, but then it changes exponentially. The player soon stumbles upon megacities, stuffed characters, either other players or the computer, but what matters here is the visual. A quick Internet search reveals, for those who do not have the game, as he is really beautiful in their environment, something that is difficult in a MMO, in many cases.

reviewText:
I have never liked mmorpg's in general though i have tried a few like WoW, Guild Wars 2, and some F2P titles. I thought the pacing and grinding was awful, i could never get past lvl 30 because by then I was too bored. This game however is something else. I'm a lvl 54 paladin by now. Here's why: there's a very captivating storyline, the gameplay mechanics are awesome (although the global cooldown might be a bit slow for some), the pacing is brilliant; you level quickly due to the main scenario quests and a thing called dungeon roulette (the game throws you in a random dungeon for an exp reward).
Perhaps the most important thing (for me at least) since I never got to the endgame of an MMO before: the community is extremely helpful for new players, be it the guild you're in or the randomly selected partymembers with which you have to clear a dungeon. People were always ready to help out.
There's also a lot of nostalgia-bombing for fans of Final Fantasy, but you absolutely don't have to have played the games beforehand.
Overall I recommend this game for newer MMORPG players as well as older players.

reviewText:
I strongly recommend this as an immersive, beautiful, extensively narrative-driven experience, to the point even the crafters and gatherers get their own storylines! While the combat is simplified, it's neither too simple nor too frustrating, and the native controller support is an absolute joy. More depth and complexity can be found in the crafting and gathering systems, although the game is still quite easy to understand.

The world, while only consisting of a few maps, is gorgeous, memorable, and full of detail, both in characters and environment.

The music is also fantastic, expressing a broad array of emotions, from the tender to the grand. The boss music as well is varied and intense and uses a variety of styles and instrumentation.

Achievement hunters might find the game a bit of a grind, as some of the achievements are literally just grindwalls, especially the ones relating to the game's minigame hub, but the fact that most game systems have achievements attached to them, and the sheer array of activities that can be done, mean achievement-hunting is fairly involved and interesting from an intellectual point of view.

reviewText: A very solid MMORPG. Sticks to many of the traditional aspects that made the genre popular while putting its own spin on things, as well as keeping the Final Fantasy vibe alive and well.  Final Fantasy fans who are not very familiar with MMORPGs will find this to be a good entry point into the genre. MMO fans should get enjoyment out of it even if they are not big into the Final Fantasy series, although they may not appreciate it as much as somebody who is very familiar with the Final Fantasy series.  Even if you aren't a fan of playing MMOs, you can still get a good experience just by playing through the main storyline.  Since the first month of game time comes free, that gives you more than enough time to play through the story if that's all you desire to do. It's definitely worth picking up and trying. It's a fun game and my MMO of choice.

reviewText:
This game lacks quite a lot to make it the most deep mmorpg around.
It has low variety of endgame armor models, low varity of impressive graphic skills (unless you're a monk class).
The grind is there, but it's not as painful as it could have been.
The amount of classes is good, but lacks some core ones (2handed dmg dealer most noticable, or dual wield damage dealer outside rogue/ninja which will  be introduced shortly after I make this review)
The story is quite lacking -some- times, but is quite epic at others.
Lack of addon support.

While these may seem as deal breakers to some the game has insane features on other departments, offering deep customization on things I didn't even know it's possible to customize. And I say that, having played all the popular (and not only) mmorpgs out there.

The overall design is just FLAWLESS, and for that the game designers have my utmost respect.I don't just mean that about the graphics. The music of the primal encounters, and other major fights are just epic, well made, inspiring pieces.
The boss encounters do have very interesting mechanics at time, but - as everything - once you conquer them they turn easier.

The game offers a LOT to do, and it's fun as long as you interract with others.
Getting into a good Guild (Free Company) is a great tip for newcommers. Many players are helpful and offer tips, and you can forge relationships which is up to you if they last.
The social experience is there, and that's a part of MMOs players neglet a lot as they blindly rush towards endgame.
I know I did that, and I've got ~450 hours played in about a month that I started this game.
That said, this game is addicting, much like any mmorpg you enjoy (won't name other popular ones)- mmorpg players will understand.

The monthly subscription is not even worth mentioning as everybody who has played mmorpgs before knows there's a vast difference in game quality, support, and other features when a game has subscription. What you pay for, you get.
Should be mentioned that the game itself is relatively cheap and comes with a 30 days sub-free to try out.
There's also a trial version available in which you can play for 2 weeks with max level 20 (and other restrictions).
I'm quite sure a game for a console costs more(about 3 times as much) and it's a 1 week experience tops.

In a market where going Free to Play seems like the only option to maintain a game, this game grows.
Credit for that goes to it's nice comunity, it's regular updates, it's low downtimes, it's nice optical and accoustical experience, and most importantly to the fact that this very game in it's 1.0 version failed horribly, shut down, and was Reborn, as the title suggests, into what is currently one of the greatest of it's kind.

Additional awesomeness points go to writers/translators or whoever named the Quests and FATEs in the game (FATE = Events that happen randomly in the world) - The naming is just great, at times I found myself just laughing at the screen with the things I was reading.
The game is so well written I cannot even begin to explain.

Overall, I feel the game was one of the most worthy purchases I've made in quite a while.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy XIV: A realm reborn is a really fun MMO. Being a WoW player from late vanilla and jumped to GW2 but got bored from it after a couple of weeks later when it was released and then jumped to Final Fantasy XIV: A realm reborn when it came to steam.I can say that i have more fun playing this MMO then when i playing GW2 and what WoW is becoming today.

To be honest i never played a Final Fantasy from the main series before but did played some DS spinoff games and came to this game and the main series as a stranger but i always wanted to try out a FF game from the main series. From have completed the main story in this MMo i think i can make a review of this game.

The first thing you should know is that if you were expecting a different MMO then World of Warcraft you gonna be disapointed but if you liked WoW from what it is you can feel a bit comfort here. You got your Kill X creatures and Collect Y things and also some talk to NPC quests but the game does not take the amount you need kill or collect as crazy as most MMo's. At later levels you mostly need to kill like 6-10 while at early levels not even more then 3. Also this game has just like WoW the Holy trinity (Tank,DPS and Healer) where also you can also play dungeons with people from other servers. But unlike WoW the normal instances are 4 man and the bigger instances 8 man but you also got a 24 man raid.

One of the key differences from WoW is that you can change to every class in the game on 1 character meaning that you dont have to make alts. I personally like this a lot and you can also be every gathering and crafting class aswell. if you level more classes you can even share some of the skills they have with other classes but not all of them, Kinda replaces the game from having no talent tree or talent skills.

The game does have a story and you progress through it by completing story quests. The game kinda forces you to follow the story quests because most of the game features are only unlocked by doing these quest making the first levels from 1 - 30 on your first class a long tutorial but after that games opens more up and the game does not really feel that slow. The game does feel a bit slow on every class first levels but as you go on the class becomes a lot more intresting.

The game also have guilds but here they are called Free Company's in this game but as you go through the story you also need to choose a Nations Grand Company wich you discover more from as you go on with the game.

Lastly if you are more of a PVP person you gonna also gonna be a bit disapointed because right now the only PVP is a 4vs4 Arena battle like in WoW and there is no way to duel people in the world and Open pvp is also not in the game.

So that kinda concludes my review on this game. if i tell about everything then this review goes out of hand. Overall i really like this MMO and wishes it to even improve more in the future. And i cant wait to do all the end game content now that i completed the main story but to be honest the story does go even further after you completed the real main story of the game. If you are unsure if you can run this game you can download a benchmark from the official site of the game where you can also Create a character beforehand so you dont have to that when you buyed the game and the benchmark is free.

Pros:

- Intersting story that isn't hard to follow and has decently played out cutscenes.

- Collision/Impact style based tab target, Not the usual tab target where you can clip through people/npc/enemies, It actually makes you dodge attacks and not just stand there bored pressing 1 , 2 , 3 repeatedly untill the mob dies like generic tab target games.

- Brings back the old type of class systems where you can do everything on the one character, An aspect I personally love because it means you dont have to play through the same story over... and over... and over... to play the different types of classes available or master different professions - you only need the one character.

- Game lets me be a Ninja Catgirl.

Cons:

- Pay to play.

- Its still tab target.

- No open world pvp/Very little pvp content.

- Servers are pretty limited, Europe/Japan/NA.

All in all its a good game, Probably not worth the full price unless you plan to dedicate your life to it, On special i'd definitely reccomend it, The amount of content you can do on your one character is staggering and i'd imagine it would take multiple months to get to that level so you wont be bored quickly.

Take a week off work, Ignore your friends and social obligations and dive into the world of Eorzea, At the very least you'll leave with a miqo'te fetish.

reviewText:
This is a beautiful, immersive and meticulously detailed game, the amazing gameplay of which will reel in franchise fans and newcomers alike. While Final Fantasy XIV is unlike its single player predecessors, the lore recognizeable by the long time FF fans creates a story with depth and character interactions generally forgotton by MMO creators.

As such, the attention to detail regarding idiosyncracies of certain characters is conveyed through their speech, and this attention to detail extends to the environment as well. Small things that one would barely notice can be found in the game, such as the pattern of shadow created by light shining through a grate, as well as that shadow adjusting alongside the in game time of day; the stitching on armors and clothing, right down to the shadows created by them on the player; and many more details that add to the game's wonderful environment.

Within this environment is gameplay that is executed uniquely, and superbly. Skills operate in a style familiar to MMO players, with a relatively short global cooldown, and individual skill cooldowns which vary depending on the strength and usefulness of the skill. Combat utilizes a TP, similar to a stamina system, while magic utilizes the classic MP. Some magic skills of which rely on a casting time, which occurs at the same time as the global cooldown, making casting fluent yet balanced. Skills can be clicked, hotkeyed, setup through user macros, and so forth. The combat truly appeals to every style of play, as well as every player through its broad range of classic Final Fantasy jobs that players can quest as.

The questing is reminiscent of other MMOs, and yet the game approaches these concepts in ways that makes them less of a grind than they could be. Rather than the traditional, Kill 50 of this monster
recommended: the quests bring these numbers down to 5s and 3s, which allows the player to take the time to actually understand WHY they are doing what they are doing.\n\nFurthermore, many players will actually be ABLE to do what they want to be doing, for the game has been optimized wonderfully. Areas are divided by loading zones, but the transition between these is so fluent and quick that it took me this long to even remember they were there. With easy to use presets such as High end PC" or "Low end laptop
hoursPlayed: adjusting settings is user friendly. If you would like to adjust things yourself, there is of course an option for custom settings.\n\nYet what truly sold me on the game, what I believe to be the greatest of its qualities, is the job change system. Many MMOs have you make one character, choose one class or destiny for them, and that's that. You're either forced to pay for some sort of reset, make a new character, completely start over or combinations of the above. NOT in Final Fantasy XIV. By simply equipping a new weapon, your stats, gear, abilities, everything switches to the role that weapon relates to, and you can head back to lower level areas to train yourself anew. This is done WITHOUT losing any of your previous progress. In fact certain jobs can use abilities learned from other classes, and often need to in order to reach their full potential. The best part is that no mistakes can be made with this system. There is no woops
voteText: you didn't train your warrior class so your strength is too low
helpfulPercent: there is some minor ability point allocation, but this is done easily and can easily be reversed. A single character can serve you for every adventure, and as such, the character creation allows you to bring that perfect character to life.\n\nOne truly could spend a few hours just in the character creator, detailing everything from the muscularity of your character, to their eye color, to the color of the tips of their hair vs the rest of their hair, etcetera, etcetera. There are four basic races each with two deviations in appeance to begin with, and the next perk that comes along is that you don't have to worry about which race has the best looking armor." Armor is purely based on class

reviewText:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this yet, but my play time should speak for itself. Do not confuse this game with the atrocity that was XIV 1.0. Square Enix literally dropped a Bahamut meteor on that game to crash the servers and reimagine it as the beautiful experience it is today. Graphics are top-notch, at least if you have a decent enough rig to play it on high quality. The community overall is incredible, though your experience will vary by server, play times, and free company allegiance (FFXIV's version of guilds). Inter-played cooperation is mandatory for endgame content, and the game sets you up very nicely to learn your chosen role well by level 50. And then if you decide you don't like that role... all you have to do is switch weapons to a different class and try again.

Hallelujah, no more multiple characters to play multiple classes; I'm looking at you, WoW. Final Fantasy's job system makes it totally feasible to level every class to cap without having to jam up a server with 10 different characters, and you might be surprised by the number of people that do exactly that. Even the crafting system is much more interactive than others I've tried, and it's the crafters and gatherers that drive the game's economy. The sense of community is all-inclusive with plenty of experienced players willing to lend a hand to upstarts, though of course don't expect everyone to be this way. Like any game, this one has its elitists but the funny part is that some of those still haven't beaten the last raid.

The best pieces of advice I can give you are these:

1) If you buy the game, give it until around level 30 to start getting truly fun. That's where you unlock your job (as opposed to your class), earning you extra abilities, and it's where the dungeons start to get really fun.
2) Once you hit level 50, there is a HUGE learning curve jump when you get to extreme mode primals and the Coils of Bahamut. That's not to say these things are impassable, but you will have to buckle down and learn the mechanics rather than expecting a clear on your first try.
3) If you get lost, use the /sh shout function in chat. Talk to someone! I can almost guarantee there will be someone around to lend a helping hand.
4) Listen when people give you advice. 90% of the time, they say it because they want to help improve their server's experience, not because they think you're a n00b that sux.
5) If you're new to the game and chose the Brynhildr server, hit up Taliel Sicilian. ;)

reviewText:
I played WoW for 6ish years on and off, and when I was gifted a subscription by my sister, who gave high praise of it, I I thought it couldn't play that differently. WoW set a very rigid image of how an MMO was set up to milk time whenever possible from the user to give the illusion of accomplishment. However, I began to notice very quickly that where WoW wasted your time, FFXIV ditched those gameplay mechanics and replaced it with something more sensable.

First, I'll give you a brief look at classes, money, and travel. Travel first because its simple. Remember all those long flight times, and even with flying mounts it didn't compensate for having to traverse the continuous, no-loading-screen continents. In FFXIV you teleport to the zone and that's it, no fuss, maybe a little walking if your destination is in the back of zone.

This ties directly into money, so that's next. In FFXIV quests actually give you some substantial amounts of money for getting everything you need from gear to materials for professions. However, repair costs ramp rather quickly, as do teleportation expenses, so part of managing your character becomes maintaining enough income to sustain everything you need. Daily quests and dungeon queues are actually important if you don't maintain any crafting/gathering skills, unlike WoW where they're a chore simply to improve a reputation with a side faction.

Classes are completely different as well. Unlike WoW where you get locked into focusing on a class unless you want to start up a whole new character, and restricted to 2 professions, FFXIV puts no barriers in your way. One character can level to 50 on every tank, dps, healer, crafting and gathering profession, and there are economic and gameplay insentives for expanding your knowledge of the game with this. Every class/profession has 2-3 cross-class skills that can enchance the abilities of another, not just combat but also in professions. The more professions you level, the easier it becomes to be independant of their version of the Auction House, as well as make boatloads of money.

Last, I guess I can put some facts down about differences in guilds and endgame. In WoW, you had to find a dedicated guild and organize parties yourself to complete 10 or 25 raids, which essentially the home to all the best-in-slot gear. They eventually added in a token system where hard 5 mans and the 10 mans would grant accumulative currency for buying equivalent or near-BiS items. However, you'd find yourself tediously working through a raid clear all week, and very rarely a boss would drop something useful to you (and you actually win the roll), making it akin to the lottery everytime you actually got something you needed.

In FFXIV, they bipassed this by making the token gear the BiS in most or all cases. If your gear dropped in 4man dungeons you were always the only class that would be able to need on it, and even in the 8 or 24mans there would rarely be another class-mate (HEH).  Also, there's nothing particularly unique a dps brings to the table than another, same with tanks and healers. Some do things better than others, but the developers saw class balance as an important thing to accomplish, UNLIKE WOW. Holy ♥♥♥♥, just remembering how useless they would make certain classes from patch to patch is infuriating as I'm writing this. That doesn't happen in FFXIV, in fact, you can randomly queue for the endgame raids everyday, multiple times a day if you want. Farming those tokens is easy, and queues are generally short. The only weekly restriction is on the current endgame dungeon's loot, which is 1 drop a week.

TL;DR: FFXIV doesn't waste your time, and seems more interested in enjoyable gameplay than epenis upgrades to flaunt over your fellow players that are more busy IRL.

reviewText:
Pros:

- Intersting story that isn't hard to follow and has decently played out cutscenes.

- Collision/Impact style based tab target, Not the usual tab target where you can clip through people/npc/enemies, It actually makes you dodge attacks and not just stand there bored pressing 1 , 2 , 3 repeatedly untill the mob dies like generic tab target games.

- Brings back the old type of class systems where you can do everything on the one character, An aspect I personally love because it means you dont have to play through the same story over... and over... and over... to play the different types of classes available or master different professions - you only need the one character.

- Game lets me be a Ninja Catgirl.

Cons:

- Pay to play.

- Its still tab target.

- No open world pvp/Very little pvp content.

- Servers are pretty limited, Europe/Japan/NA.

All in all its a good game, Probably not worth the full price unless you plan to dedicate your life to it, On special i'd definitely reccomend it, The amount of content you can do on your one character is staggering and i'd imagine it would take multiple months to get to that level so you wont be bored quickly.

Take a week off work, Ignore your friends and social obligations and dive into the world of Eorzea, At the very least you'll leave with a miqo'te fetish.

reviewText:
This is a beautiful, immersive and meticulously detailed game, the amazing gameplay of which will reel in franchise fans and newcomers alike. While Final Fantasy XIV is unlike its single player predecessors, the lore recognizeable by the long time FF fans creates a story with depth and character interactions generally forgotton by MMO creators.

As such, the attention to detail regarding idiosyncracies of certain characters is conveyed through their speech, and this attention to detail extends to the environment as well. Small things that one would barely notice can be found in the game, such as the pattern of shadow created by light shining through a grate, as well as that shadow adjusting alongside the in game time of day; the stitching on armors and clothing, right down to the shadows created by them on the player; and many more details that add to the game's wonderful environment.

Within this environment is gameplay that is executed uniquely, and superbly. Skills operate in a style familiar to MMO players, with a relatively short global cooldown, and individual skill cooldowns which vary depending on the strength and usefulness of the skill. Combat utilizes a TP, similar to a stamina system, while magic utilizes the classic MP. Some magic skills of which rely on a casting time, which occurs at the same time as the global cooldown, making casting fluent yet balanced. Skills can be clicked, hotkeyed, setup through user macros, and so forth. The combat truly appeals to every style of play, as well as every player through its broad range of classic Final Fantasy jobs that players can quest as.

The questing is reminiscent of other MMOs, and yet the game approaches these concepts in ways that makes them less of a grind than they could be. Rather than the traditional, Kill 50 of this monster
recommended: the quests bring these numbers down to 5s and 3s, which allows the player to take the time to actually understand WHY they are doing what they are doing.\n\nFurthermore, many players will actually be ABLE to do what they want to be doing, for the game has been optimized wonderfully. Areas are divided by loading zones, but the transition between these is so fluent and quick that it took me this long to even remember they were there. With easy to use presets such as High end PC" or "Low end laptop
hoursPlayed: adjusting settings is user friendly. If you would like to adjust things yourself, there is of course an option for custom settings.\n\nYet what truly sold me on the game, what I believe to be the greatest of its qualities, is the job change system. Many MMOs have you make one character, choose one class or destiny for them, and that's that. You're either forced to pay for some sort of reset, make a new character, completely start over or combinations of the above. NOT in Final Fantasy XIV. By simply equipping a new weapon, your stats, gear, abilities, everything switches to the role that weapon relates to, and you can head back to lower level areas to train yourself anew. This is done WITHOUT losing any of your previous progress. In fact certain jobs can use abilities learned from other classes, and often need to in order to reach their full potential. The best part is that no mistakes can be made with this system. There is no woops

reviewText:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this yet, but my play time should speak for itself. Do not confuse this game with the atrocity that was XIV 1.0. Square Enix literally dropped a Bahamut meteor on that game to crash the servers and reimagine it as the beautiful experience it is today. Graphics are top-notch, at least if you have a decent enough rig to play it on high quality. The community overall is incredible, though your experience will vary by server, play times, and free company allegiance (FFXIV's version of guilds). Inter-played cooperation is mandatory for endgame content, and the game sets you up very nicely to learn your chosen role well by level 50. And then if you decide you don't like that role... all you have to do is switch weapons to a different class and try again.

Hallelujah, no more multiple characters to play multiple classes; I'm looking at you, WoW. Final Fantasy's job system makes it totally feasible to level every class to cap without having to jam up a server with 10 different characters, and you might be surprised by the number of people that do exactly that. Even the crafting system is much more interactive than others I've tried, and it's the crafters and gatherers that drive the game's economy. The sense of community is all-inclusive with plenty of experienced players willing to lend a hand to upstarts, though of course don't expect everyone to be this way. Like any game, this one has its elitists but the funny part is that some of those still haven't beaten the last raid.

The best pieces of advice I can give you are these:

1) If you buy the game, give it until around level 30 to start getting truly fun. That's where you unlock your job (as opposed to your class), earning you extra abilities, and it's where the dungeons start to get really fun.
2) Once you hit level 50, there is a HUGE learning curve jump when you get to extreme mode primals and the Coils of Bahamut. That's not to say these things are impassable, but you will have to buckle down and learn the mechanics rather than expecting a clear on your first try.
3) If you get lost, use the /sh shout function in chat. Talk to someone! I can almost guarantee there will be someone around to lend a helping hand.
4) Listen when people give you advice. 90% of the time, they say it because they want to help improve their server's experience, not because they think you're a n00b that sux.
5) If you're new to the game and chose the Brynhildr server, hit up Taliel Sicilian. ;)

reviewText:
NEW VERSION
I got in after about a day of trying to get into the server. Once you're settled in, it takes at most 30 seconds to queue into the server on prime time.

I play a tank and I get a lot of love because of that. It appears tanks are extremely rare in this game. I always get the award for playing the most needed class. This is an actual reward in the game.

TUTORIAL
The tutorial is huge and extremely good. It's not the type of tutorial that holds your hand, treats you like a baby and gives you little bites. It's a big tutorial that lasts throughout the entire first half of the leveling process. More features of the game open up over time, similar to Guild Wars 2's new player experience but not silly like in GW2.

There are obvious tutorial instances that teach the basics of the trinity and let you actually train and figure out how the mechanics work before you get thrown into a dungeon.

DUNGEONS + DUNGEON ROULETTE
There's lots of them. Main quest dungeons, sidequest dungeons, instances that only have a boss in them, etc.

How does it prevent dungeons from being empty? The duty roulette system gives you a massive boost in rewards once per day. You don't pick a specific dungeon. The roulette picks it for you, meaning you never know what you'll get. Meanwhile, players who need to do a dungeon for their quests/items/gear will get their parties filled.

I'll compare this with GW2 that has a party finding/LFG tool. In there, you need to actually search for party members, which works ok witht he LFG tool. In Guild Wars 1 there was no such tool and you could end up waiting for hours to get a party.

WAITING FOR PARTY
As I said before, the roulette fills up parties for massive rewards. It's not unheard of to get nearly an entire level worth of exp using the daily roulette. But how fast does it fill up? For me, as soon as I click the button to start up the search.

Why? Because I'm a tank and the guy who dragged me into this game is a healer. We only need to find 2 more DPS guys, of which there are bazillions.

As a tank, I get friend requests all over. People are overly friendly to me. In chats and forums there is talk of not enough tanks in this game. Since I am one, I don't have a problem. But if you prefer playing DPS, you may end up waiting for a while. I've seen players complain about waiting 30 minutes or more.

COMBAT
Okay, I'm not a fan of the combat. All I do is press 2 buttons, maybe 3 and just rotate through them. Dungeons may have a few more rotations. Just fighting in the overworld is pretty lame.

Dungeon encounters are quite interesting though. You have the regular trash mobs leading up to the boss. Early bosses are pushovers. They gradually get better

CRAFTING
There's a huge expansive crafting system. In fact, the gathering classes and crafting classes are quite fleshed out, similar to the combat classes.

In the beginning it is the old basic ingredient gathering and putting them together. Later on, you need to start making choices, mixed in with a bit of RNG. Using CP, Crafting Points, which are similar to mana points, you can activate skills that can improve the quality of an item, do nothing for a step (this has a use), make you more focused, etc.

Again, comparing with GW2... In GW2 you put 2-4 items together and press craft. That's it. Here, you put 2-5 (or 6?) items together, but they can be of different qualities, which affects the outcome. You activate skills which further change the outcome. Crafting one item takes several steps. These are not ingredient steps but attacks" you do. It's not braindead coma crafting.

USEFULNESS OF CRAFTING IN EARLY LEVELS
Crafting is actually useful here

I didn't even need to craft items for my char to use because I got all ym gear from main-quest quest rewards. But that's just one class. There are many other classes and your character can take them all. You onlyneed one character. To swap jobs you swap out your gearset.\n\nWhen I start building my disciples of magic classes

HOUSING

reviewText:
They really improved this game- and I love that I can choose to play the same character on PC or PS4 depending on which I'd rather be on at the moment (unrelated to the PC version, but the controls work very well on PS4).

It has a bit of a slow pace, and of course it's an MMO so there's grinding involved- but the game looks good, is easy to use and unlike FFXI you can solo your way through anything even if you're not a great player, while also making it easy and rewarding to group up both for dungeons and world events.

It has pretty much every feature you'd expect for a modern MMO, an involving story, variety to do, and it has likely the best online community of the AAA group.

You won't feel any adrenaline playing this game, but if you're looking for something relaxing it's perfect. Need a break from enemies? There's entire classes devoted to gathering and crafting you can switch to on the fly (one character can have every single class, almost like specs in another game with no respec cost). There's many mini games, even an entire zone dedicated solely to mini games (the Gold Saucer behaves much like the one in FFVII).

Gathering professions are considerably more involving than other games; and even fishing's enjoyable (though, a bit limited- take in small doses).

The game looks and sounds nice, but some of the voice acting is... questionable. Also, there's still a sub fee.

That said- for a mainstream MMO it's one of the best, and I'm hard pressed to think of one that has the same general appeal for the f2p. Sides, a month of gameplay for an hour's work at minimum wage, or two starbucks coffees, has never seemed unreasonable to me.

reviewText: As someone who has played just about every MMO and quite a few for many years. This really got its hooks into me, but only for a few weeks. Very much enjoyed the huge amount of classes and the ability to switch between any of them at anytime. The combat is fun, the quests and dungeons are very fast paced and enjoyable. The graphics are quite wonderful and has a great flow to the game. But after only a few weeks I had already maxed out the class I enjoyed most and had done all end game content but one raid and was at a point where all I could do was rerun the same raid 2-3 times a day to farm tokens for better gear. Felt like in was on repeat every time I logged in, besides all that it is a solid MMO with much more content added since I last played. If your a completionist this game is for you, with about 13+ classes to max and so many quests and storylines everywhere and a huge world to explore. But if your looking for a MMO you can log into and feel like your doing something new and exciting regularly this is not for you, a lot of grinding and rerunning in this game.

reviewText:
This game is beyong anything I could have ever imagined.

Gameplay wise, the game is smooth, easy going, and rather slow paced. The start of the game may seem a bit grindy, but the more you progress, the more features you unlock. Every quest you complete seems rewarding.

The environment one of the most beautiful I have seen in any MMO, being easily comparable to games like Tera Rising. The graphics are absolutely phenominal and the attention to detail makes the game really immersive.

The community as far as what I have experienced contains some of the nicest people I have ever met in an online game. People are inclusive and ready to help new players out.

The only issues I have had with this game are a global cooldown of 2.5 seconds, although you  get used to it quite fast, and the lack of voiceacting in cutscenes. Voiceacting could have deserved a little more focus, especially seeing as when you actually get to experience it, it is absolutely great, funny and immersive. That's literally the only issues I have had though, and if you are able to ignore these minor things, you are going to have a one-of-a-kind experience.

I will update my experience with this game the more I progress through it.

reviewText:
Ok. First of all I am not an MMORPG fan. I Have played 2 before and not for very long. I swore I would NEVER pay for a subscription fee.

Now I have paid for one and do not regret it at all.
This game is awesome. The amount of stuff you can do in game is impressive as are the graphics and framerate if your PC can handle it.  I have so far played as 2 different classes and to me they feel different. I play them different, which is a good thing.

People are generally pretty helpful to noobs and not total d1ckfaces, Although you do get some of those too to be fair.
The community seems to be pretty tightly knit and friendly. Within a few minutes on each of 2 servers I have played on, I have been invited to join Free Companys. Or Guilds if you prefer.

There does seem to be a fairly steep learning curve with menus and such, and the game doesn't really explain them very well if at all. Stick with it, ask questions and experiment and after a while you will get the hang of it.

The map can be daunting at times. I find I'm getting better at it all of the time, but initially it can really mess you up. Especially when there can be different height levels in some areas such as towns. The map does not shift up or down to accomodate your vantage point.

When playing with a party, it seems you will share/split experience. That can be pretty cool.

Audio is good and has some classic FF music, which is nice.
Graphics are incredibly vibrant and colorful, like you'd expect from a FF game.

Character interactions are a little tedious. You read alsmot EVERYTHING. Even most cutscenes are not voiced. Although there are a few.

Account creation is a  little weird. Especially when you have to use the game client+the website+subscribe and link your account. This could have been a little less confusing.

When a friend wants to join you and they just got  the game it is entirely possible that they may not be able to join you. The  world you are on might be full. They can't wait for someone just to logoff. That doesn't seem to work. They have to hope that someone deletes a character at some point I have a lvl 12 character in one world and my friend cannot join me. I had to create a new character on a new world to play with them.

One last thing: I believe, (and I might be wrong about this), that you get 8 character slots per world. To give you an idea, there are roughly 8 worlds per server area and about 7 server areas. That is pretty impressive.

Would I recommend this game to people? Sure if you are a Final Fantasy fan or an MMO fan.
Not for everybody...but I'm loving it so far.
